revision.text:
'''Abortion in Israel''' is permitted when determined by a termination committee under various circumstances, with the vast majority of cases being approved {{as of|2014|lc=y}}.<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.cbs.gov.il/reader/newhodaot/hodaa_template.html?hodaa=201605367 Applications for Pregnancy Termination in 2014 ]</ref> The rate of abortion in Israel has steadily declined since 1988.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Compared to the world, abortion rates in Israel are moderate. According to government data, in Israel, abortion rates in 2014 are 9.7 per 1,000 women of childbearing age, lower than England (16.2) and the United States (13.2).<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Abortion in Israel had been illegal prior to 1977. It became legal subject to termination committee approval under the penal code of 1978.<ref>[https://www.nevo.co.il/law_html/Law01/073_022.htm The Penal Regulations (Termination of Pregnancy), 5738-1978 ]</ref> Prior to 2014, however, approval for an [[abortion]] in [[Israel]] by a termination committee was given under more limited circumstances, such as if the woman is unmarried, because of age (if the woman is under the age of 18 - the legal marriage age in Israel - or over the age of 40), the pregnancy was conceived under illegal circumstances (rape, statutory rape, etc.) or an incestuous relationship, [[birth defects]], risk of health to the mother, and life of the mother.<ref name=israelabortion>Update: Israel's abortion law now among world's most liberal -- Free abortions for all women http://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-abortion-law-now-among-worlds-most-liberal/</ref> Subsequent to 2014, abortion up to the age of 33 can be provided for under the nationally funded health basket.<ref>[http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4471052,00.html סל התרופות 2014: הפלות חינם גם ללא סיבה רפואית]</ref>
According to the Israel Central Bureau of Statistics report from 2004, in 2003, most abortion requests were granted, with 19,500 legal abortions performed and 200 requests for abortion denied. Reasons for termination went as follows: The woman was unmarried (42%), because of illegal circumstances (11%), health risks to the woman (about 20%), age of the woman (11%), and fetal birth defects (about 17%).<ref name="cbs.gov.il">{{He icon}} Central Bureau of Statistics. (August 30, 2005). {{DOClink|[http://www.cbs.gov.il/hodaot2005n/01_05_191b.doc Patterns of Fertility in Israel in 2004]}}. Retrieved February 12, 2007.</ref> Women who would not qualify for an abortion under the statutory scheme may seek an abortion at a private clinic.
It was reported in 2012 that about half of all abortions in Israel were performed in private clinics, i. e., without committee approval. Women who undergo such an abortion do not face criminal penalties, but physicians who perform them face a fine or up to five years' imprisonment; however, there have been no known prosecutions of physicians for performing non-committee-approved abortions.<ref>https://www.loc.gov/law/help/israel_2012-007460_IL_FINAL.pdf</ref> It was also reported in 2007 and 2011 that about 40,000 abortions take place in Israel every year, about half of them committee approved.<ref name="cbs.gov.il"/><ref>http://www.israeltoday.co.il/NewsItem/tabid/178/nid/22647/Default.aspx</ref>
==Legal position== Clauses 312-321 of the 1977 [[Criminal code|penal code]] limit the circumstances when an abortion is legal in Israel. Abortions must be approved by a termination committee. Abortions can only be performed by licensed [[gynecology|gynecologists]] in recognized medical facilities that are specifically and publicly recognized as a provider of abortions.<ref name="penal">[[wikisource:he:חוק העונשין|Israeli penal code]] at the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] [[Wikisource]].</ref> However, the Israeli Cabinet updated the 1977 law in 2014 to allow [[abortion on demand]] for nearly every woman in the country seeking an abortion.<ref name=israelabortion />
===Circumstances under which abortion is approved=== Under a 1977 abortion law, a termination committee can approve an abortion, under sub-section 316a,<ref name="penal" /> in the following circumstances:
# The woman is younger than the legal marriage age in Israel (which currently is 18, raised from 17 in April 2013),<ref>Ynetnews.com, 11.4.13: [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4449522,00.html Knesset raises marriage age to 18].</ref> or older than forty. (This was later amended to also include women under the age of twenty.)<ref name=israelabortion /> # The pregnancy was conceived under illegal circumstances ([[rape]], [[statutory rape]], etc.), in an [[incest]]uous relationship, or outside of marriage. # The [[fetus]] may have a physical or mental [[birth defect]]. # Continued pregnancy may put the woman's life in risk, or damage her physically or mentally.
Previously, cases where the woman is between the ages of 20-33, and/or was granted an abortion due to the baby having been conceived under illegal circumstances or incest, the fetus had a serious physical or mental defect, the mother was unmarried, or the mother's health was in danger, the state pays for the abortion. However, the law was modified in 2014 to allow a free state-funded "health basket" for any woman seeking an abortion.<ref name=israelabortion /> Women who get pregnant while serving in the IDF are entitled to free, state-funded abortion.<ref>http://www.jta.org/news/article/2012/07/09/3100216/op-ed-dont-set-back-reproductive-rights-for-israeli-women</ref><ref>[http://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-abortion-law-now-among-worlds-most-liberal/ Israel’s abortion law now among world's most liberal]</ref>
In practice, most requests for abortion that qualify for the above are granted, and leniency is shown especially under the clause for emotional or psychological damage to the pregnant woman. The committees approve 98% of requests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-abortion-law-now-among-worlds-most-liberal/#ixzz2pfY4gXn0|title=Israel's abortion law now among world’s most liberal|author=Debra Kamin|publisher=The Times of Israel|date=January 6, 2014}}</ref>
===Structure of the committee=== There are 41 termination committees operating in public or private hospitals across Israel. These committees consist of three members, two of which are licensed [[physician]]s, and one a [[social work]]er.<ref name="penal" /> Of the two physicians, one must be an expert on [[obstetrics and gynaecology]], and the other one either OB/GYN, [[internal medicine]], [[psychiatry]], [[general practitioner|family medicine]], or [[public health]]. At least one member must be a woman. Six separate committees consider abortion requests when the fetus is beyond 24 weeks old.
==Abortion debate in Israel== There is an [[abortion debate]] in Israel, although it is sidelined by more publicized and controversial issues. The debate as to the morality of abortion is antecedent to the debate about [[separation of church and state|separation of religion and state]] in the context of Israel as a [[Jewish State]] and a [[democracy|democratic]].
[[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] organizations, including political parties, strongly oppose abortion because [[Halakhah|Jewish law]] views abortion as a (lesser) form of murder. Political parties that champion this view include [[Shas]], a [[Sephardic]] Haredi party; [[United Torah Judaism]], an [[Ashkenazi]] Haredi party; and HaBayit HaYehudi ([[Jewish Home]]), a [[Religious Zionist]] party. A study published in 2001 found that opposition to abortion among Israelis was correlated to strong religious beliefs - particularly [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] beliefs - below-average income, larger family size, and identification with [[right-wing politics]].<ref>Remennick, Larissa I., & Hetsron, Amir. (2001). [http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/abs/10.1111/0038-4941.00033?cookieSet=1&journalCode=ssqu Public Attitudes toward Abortion in Israel: A Research Note]. ''Social Science Quarterly, 82 (2),'' 420–431. Retrieved February 12, 2007.</ref>
The left-wing party [[Meretz]] argues in favor of legalized abortion for reasons of [[personal liberty]]. In 2006, [[Knesset|MK]] Zehava Gal-On of [[Meretz]] proposed a bill that would eliminate the termination committees, effectively [[decriminalization|decriminalizing]] unrestricted abortion. Gal-On argued that women with financial means can have abortions in private [[clinic]]s, bypassing the committee and therefore gaining rights based on their wealth. The bill was rejected by a wide margin.
When the relevant section of the penal code was originally written, it contained a "social clause" permitting women to seek abortions for social reasons, such as economic distress.<ref name="penal" /> The clause was withdrawn in 1980 under the initiative of the [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] parties (see [[Shas]], [[United Torah Judaism]], and [[National Religious Party]]).
This clause is still under debate in Israel. In 2004, [[Knesset|MK]] Reshef Chen of [[Shinui]] submitted an addendum to reinstate the clause, arguing that under present circumstances, women with financial problems must lie to the termination committee to obtain approval under the emotional or psychological damage clause, and that "no advanced country compels its citizens to lie in order to preserve [[religion|religious]], [[male chauvinism|chauvinistic]], patronizing archaic values". Women's organizations such as [[Naamat]] supported the proposal.<ref>{{He icon}} Ruti, Sinai. (June 8, 2004). "[http://news.walla.co.il/?w=//553906 Proposal: Women in poor financial condition will be able to get an abortion]." ''[[Walla!]].'' Retrieved February 3, 2007.</ref>
Women's organizations such as Naamat<ref>[http://www.naamat.org/ Naamat official site]</ref> and [[Shdulat HaNashim]] (women's lobby)<ref>{{He icon}} [http://www.iwn.org.il/inner.asp?newsid=53 IWN official site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819171104/http://www.iwn.org.il/inner.asp?newsid=53 |date=August 19, 2007 }}, legal pregnancy termination in Israel</ref> argue in favor for [[feminist]], [[pro-choice]] reasons, such as [[reproductive rights]].
[[Efrat (organization)|Efrat]]<ref>[http://www.efrat.org.il/en/ Efrat official site]</ref> is a religious organization that lobbies against abortions, as well as offering financial support to women who are considering abortion for economic reasons. Efrat's campaign includes stickers with the slogan, "Don't abort me" ({{lang-he|אל תפילו אותי}}). Be'ad Chaim<ref>[http://www.beadchaim.com/ Be'ad Chaim Official site]</ref> is a Messianic Christian anti-abortion non-profit association. Another organization which provides financial support and counseling to women considering abortion is Just One Life (J.O.L.) <ref>[http://www.justonelife.org/ Just One Life - Official site]</ref> - which in Hebrew is known as Nefesh Achat B'Yisrael.
==See also== * [[Judaism and abortion]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Abortion in Asia}} {{Abortion}}
[[Category:Abortion in Israel|*]] [[Category:Israeli law]] [[Category:Abortion by country]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox medical person | honorific_prefix = | name = Anne Ferguson | honorific_suffix = [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow|FRCPG]] [[Royal College of Physicians|FRCP]] [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh|FRCPE]] [[Royal College of Pathologists|FRCP]] [[FRSE]] | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=y|1941|07|21}} | birth_place = [[Glasgow]], Scotland | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|1998|12|21|1941|07|21}} | death_place = [[Edinburgh]] | death_cause = [[pancreatic cancer]] | nationality = | citizenship = | education = [[University of Glasgow]] | occupation = physician, academic | years_active = 1969–1998 | known_for = research into [[coeliac disease]] and [[Immune tolerance#Oral tolerance and hypersensitivity|oral tolerance]] | relations = John Ferguson (1966–1989 his death) (husband)
Gerald Collee (1995–1998 her death) (husband) | website = | profession = | field = [[mucosal immunology]], [[gastroenterology]] | work_institutions = [[Western Infirmary]]
[[University of Edinburgh]]
[[Western General Hospital]] | specialism = | research_field = | notable_works = | prizes = | child = | module2 = | signature = }} '''Anne Ferguson''' {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|FRSE|FRCPG|FRCP|FRCPE|FRCP|FRSE}} (26 July 1941 – 21 December 1998) was a Scottish physician, [[clinical researcher]] and expert in [[inflammatory bowel disease]]. She was considered one of the most distinguished [[Gastroenterology|gastroenterologists]] in Britain. == Education and early work == Anne Glen was born in Glasgow in 1941 to Monica and John Glen. She was educated at [[Notre Dame High School, Glasgow|Notre Dame High School]] and the [[University of Glasgow]], graduating with a first class honours [[Bachelor of Science|BSc]] in [[physiology]] in 1961, followed in 1964 with a [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery|MBChB]] with honours. She won the Brunton Medal for the most distinguished graduate in medicine at the University.{{Cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12014450.Professor_Anne_Ferguson/|title=Professor Anne Ferguson|website=The Herald|location=Glasgow|access-date=24 February 2017}}{{Cite journal|last=MacDonald|first=Thomas T.|date=March 1999|title=Professor Anne Ferguson (Anne Collee) 1941–1998|url=http://journals.lww.com/jpgn/fulltext/1999/03000/professor_anne_ferguson__anne_collee__1941_1998.1.aspx|journal=Journal of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition|volume=28|issue=3|pages=9A|issn=0277-2116}} In 1969, after completing her medical training, she became a lecturer at the Department of Bacteriology and Immunology in Glasgow's [[Western Infirmary]] teaching hospital. While working at the hospital she carried out research on the role of [[Intraepithelial lymphocyte|intra-epithelial lymphocytes]] in intestinal immunity, receiving her PhD in 1974. == Career == In 1975 she was appointed as a Senior Lecturer at the [[University of Edinburgh]], also becoming a consultant at the Gastrointestinal Unit at the [[Western General Hospital]] in Edinburgh.{{Cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/4984|title=Munks Roll Details for Anne Ferguson|website=munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk|access-date=24 February 2017}} In 1987 she was appointed to a personal professorship in gastroenterology. From 1991 to 1994 she was head of the [[University of Edinburgh Medical School|Department of Medicine]] at the University. She published more than 250 papers in peer-reviewed academic journals, published three books and contributed chapters to many other books. Her research provided new insights into the mechanisms responsible for [[Crohn's disease|Crohn's]] and [[Coeliac disease|coeliac]] diseases which led to significant advances in the therapy of these conditions. She also carried out significant research on [[Immune tolerance#Oral tolerance and hypersensitivity|oral tolerance]]. She served on the [[Committee on Safety of Medicines]], the [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]] Gene Therapy Advisory Board, and the [[Transmissible spongiform encephalopathy|Spongiform Encephalopathy]] Advisory Committee. At the time of her death she was President of the [[Society for Mucosal Immunology]]. She was a consultant proving advice and training to the [[International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh|International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research in Bangladesh]]. == Awards and honours == In 1979 Ferguson was awarded the [[Francis Avery Jones|Sir Francis Avery Jones]] research medal of the [[British Society of Gastroenterology]], the highest research award that the national gastroenterology body confers on its researchers. Such was the regard for her research, clinical expertise and teaching that she received fellowships from the Royal Colleges of Physicians of [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow|Glasgow]] (1975), [[Royal College of Physicians|London]] (1977) and [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh|Edinburgh]] (1981). She also received a fellowship from the [[Royal College of Pathologists]] in 1984. In 1990 she became a [[Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. == Personal life == In 1966 she married John Ferguson, a sociology lecturer at the [[University of Strathclyde]], and together they adopted two children, a girl and a boy. John Ferguson died of cancer in 1989. She married Professor Gerald Collee, Emeritus Professor of Medical Microbiology at the University of Edinburgh in 1995.{{Cite journal|date=December 1998|title=Obituary–In Memory of Professor Anne Ferguson, President of SMI|url=http://www.socmucimm.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Volume-6-Issue-4.pdf|journal=Mucosal Immunology Update|pages=3–4}} In her youth Ferguson represented the University of Glasgow in athletics as a [[Middle-distance running|middle-distance runner]]. She was also on the [[Basketballscotland|Scottish women's basketball team]]. She enjoyed hill walking and mountaineering, and once visited the [[Himalayas]] with her first husband. Ferguson died of [[pancreatic cancer]] in Edinburgh on 21 December 1998. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ferguson, Anne}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:1998 deaths]] [[Category:People from Glasgow]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Glasgow]] [[Category:20th-century Scottish medical doctors]] [[Category:Scottish women medical doctors]] [[Category:Clinical research]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:British gastroenterologists]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Physicians]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Pathologists]]

An '''anxiotropic''' agent is one that modifies [[anxiety]], a human emotion that has [[Homology (biology)|homologous]] processes in animals. In [[psychopharmacology]] anxiotropic agents consist of two categories of [[Psychoactive drug|psychoactive]] drugs: [[anxiolytic]]s that reduce anxiety and may be used therapeutically, and [[anxiogenic]] compounds that increase anxiety.
Most anxiolytic agents are [[minor tranquilizers]], the founding compound of which was [[meprobamate]], marketed in the United States as Miltown. Meprobamate was eventually eclipsed by the [[benzodiazepines]]. The target of both categories of anxiotropic compounds is the [[GABAA receptor]].
Globally, the two most widely used [[psychoactive]] drugs are anxiotropic agents: [[ethanol]], an anxiolytic, and [[caffeine]], an anxiogenic. While intake of both ethanol and caffeine has been shown to exert an anxiolytic effect, their withdrawal is associated with anxiogenic effects.<ref>{{cite journal|title= The anxiolytic and anxiogenic actions of ethanol in a mouse model|date=2013-03-25 |pmid=2899150 | volume=40 |journal=J Pharm Pharmacol |pages=197-202 | last1 = Costall | first1 = B | last2 = Kelly | first2 = ME | last3 = Naylor | first3 = RJ}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title= Anxiety-like behaviors following chronic ethanol exposure|date=2013-03-25 |pmid=15642625 | doi=10.1016/j.neubiorev.2004.11.001 |volume=28 |journal=Neurosci Biobehav Rev |pages=837-50 | last1 = Kliethermes | first1 = CL}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{psych-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Autism Awareness Ribbon.png|thumb|200px|Autism Awareness Ribbon]]
The '''Autism Awareness Campaign – United Kingdom''' was launched in 2000 by British parents and carers [[Ivan Corea (Autism Campaign and Journalist)|Ivan Corea]] and his wife Charika Corea in response to the [[autism]] diagnosis of their son, Charin.
==Objectives== According to their website, Autism Awareness Campaign – United Kingdom was started in 2000 "to campaign on behalf of parents, carers, children and adults with autism and [[Asperger syndrome|Asperger's syndrome]], for better public services in health, education, specialist speech therapy and respite care; for independent research into the causes of autism; for greater public awareness on Autism and Asperger's Syndrome", as well as other areas where they believe there is a shortfall in public-service provision.<ref>[http://uk_autism.tripod.com/ Autism Awareness Campaign – United Kingdom.] Official website, home page. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> They have lobbied for greater "awareness" of the condition and for independent research on the [[causes of autism]].<ref>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200607/cmhansrd/cm070307/halltext/70307h0009.htm#070307132000005 7 Mar 2007 : Column 497WH, Autistic Children (Education).] UK Parliament, 7 March 2007. Retrieved on 8 July 2008.</ref>
==Events== [[File:Parliament at Sunset.JPG|thumb|200px|British Prime Minister Tony Blair met with autism campaigner Ivan Corea and Lee Scott MP in the Palace of Westminster in 2007 to discuss autism]] [[File:15-11-05 101 Monument.jpg|thumb|200px|London 2012 Olympic bid]] ;2002 United Kingdom Autism Awareness Year
The Autism Awareness Campaign of 2002 initiated debates in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament of the UK]] and the [[Scottish Parliament]] for Autism Awareness Year, supported by 800 UK organisations including the British Institute of Brain Injured Children, The Disabilities Trust, Autism London and the [[National Autistic Society]].<ref name=UKParliament9Jan>[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200102/cmhansrd/vo020109/halltext/20109h02.htm 9 Jan 2002 : Column 226WH, Autism.] UK Parliament, 9 January 2002. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> A major conference on autism was held at the [[King's Fund]] in London and the first ever service for autism was launched in 2002 by the couple who initiated [[Autism Sunday]] - it was held at [[St Paul's Cathedral]]. Autism Sunday is now a massive worldwide event, celebrated in many countries.
;2007 House of Commons autism debate and meeting with Prime Minister The Autism Awareness Campaign helped raise "awareness" about the condition in 2007 in the [[British House of Commons]] when [[Lee Scott (UK politician)|Lee Scott]], MP for [[Ilford North (UK Parliament constituency)|Ilford North]], brought a debate on autistic children.<ref>[http://www.bloggernews.net/15126 UK Autism Westminster Debate: British MPs focus attention onto Autism.] Blogger News Network, 10 March 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
Ivan Corea met with the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]], [[Tony Blair]] and Lee Scott MP in April 2007. He presented the Prime Minister with a report calling for a national strategy on autism and a 10-year plan of action in the UK.<ref>[http://www.number-10.gov.uk/output/Page11529.asp PM praised for speaking out on autism.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525231619/http://www.number-10.gov.uk/output/Page11529.asp |date=May 25, 2007 }} 10 Downing Street, 25 April 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> The call for an urgent review on autism services was supported by leading British charities and community organisations including faith communities.<ref>[http://www.huliq.com/20018/uk-prime-minister-tony-blair-meets-autism-campaigners UK Prime Minister Tony Blair meets Autism Campaigners.] Huliq News 27 April 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> Parliamentarians signed an [[early day motion]] on autism (EDM 1359) backing the call for a national strategy on autism and change in policy for people with autism and [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref>Gapes, Mike. [http://edmi.parliament.uk/edmi/EDMDetails.aspx?EDMID=33138&SESSION=885 Early Day Motion: EDM 1359 on Autism.] House of Commons - UK Parliament, 26 April 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> Ivan Corea met with the British Prime Minister-in-Waiting, [[Gordon Brown]] in June 2007 to urge him to launch the national strategy and 10-year plan on autism,<ref name=BrownUrged>[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/74559.php Gordon Brown Urged To Take Decisive Action On Autism.] Medical News Today, 19 June 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> particularly in building state-of-the-art "autism schools".<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/society/health/help+autistic+children++call/591682 Help Autistic Children.] Channel 4 Television, 8 July 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
'''World Autism Awareness Day'''
The Autism Awareness Campaign UK were involved in the first United Nations World Autism Awareness Day, declared by the [[UN General Assembly]] on Wednesday 2 April 2008 on the recommendation of the State of [[Qatar]].
The campaign called on the United Nations Secretary-General, [[Ban Ki-moon]] to launch a world autism strategy. A CNN interview with presenter Max Foster was televised to mark World Autism Awareness Day on 2 April 2008.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/video/#/video/health/2008/04/02/intv.austism.corea.cnn Fighting for Autism: Max Foster interviews Ivan Corea.] CNN.com, 2 April 2008. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> International coverage about the Autism Awareness Campaign UK was also given on [[Associated Press]] and the campaigners received national coverage in the United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.gm.tv/index.cfm?articleid=28952 GMTV features the Autism Awareness Campaign UK] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410040648/http://www.gm.tv/index.cfm?articleid=28952 |date=April 10, 2008 }}. GMTV, 25 April 2008. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
The campaigners released a film to mark the United Nations World Autism Awareness Day with British peer the [[Baroness Uddin]] in the [[House of Lords]].[[Open Every Door]], written by the award winning Sri Lanka-born singer and songwriter, [[Nimal Mendis]], was aired on the UN World Autism Awareness Day by CNN.
'''London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic bid''' [[Sebastian Coe|Lord Coe]] appointed Ivan Corea as a [[London 2012 Olympic bid]] Ambassador; the Autism Awareness Campaign UK were fully involved with the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic bid.<ref>[http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/search/575826.Buckhurst_Hill_man_called_up_to_back_Olympic_bid/ Buckhurst Hill man called up to back Olympic bid.] ''The Guardian'', 8 March 2005. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/search/575199.Support_for_Olympics_results_in_special_posting/ Support for Olympics results in special posting.] ''The Guardian'', 7 March 2005. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
==See also== * [[List of autism-related topics]] * [[World Autism Awareness Day]] * [[Autism rights movement]] * [[Autism]]
==References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://uk_autism.tripod.com Autism Awareness Campaign UK: Campaigning for all people with Autism] (official website)

revision.text:
{{news release|1=article|date=October 2017}} [[File:Children's Oncology Group logo.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Children's Oncology Group]] The '''Children’s Oncology Group''' ('''COG'''), a clinical trials group supported by the [[National Cancer Institute]] (NCI), is the world’s largest organization devoted exclusively to pediatric cancer research.<ref name="NCI Cancer Bulletin">{{cite web|title=Pediatric Oncology Partnerships Are Models for Success|url=http://www.cancer.gov/aboutnci/ncicancerbulletin/archive/2008/031808/page1|work=NCI Cancer Bulletin}}</ref> The COG conducts a spectrum of [[clinical research]] and [[translational research]] trials for infants, children, adolescents, and young adults with cancer.
Almost all centers that treat children with cancer in the US and Canada are part of the COG, with more than 200 centers in the United States, Canada, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Australia, and New Zealand. The member institutions have multidisciplinary teams consisting of physicians, research scientists, nurses, psychologists, pharmacists and other specialists.<ref name="O'Leary">{{cite journal|last=O'Leary|first=M|author2=Krailo M|author3=Anderson JR|author4=Reaman GH|title=Progress in Childhood Cancer: 50 Years of Research Collaboration, a Report from the Children's Oncology Group|journal=Seminars in Oncology|year=2008|volume=35|pages=484–493|doi=10.1053/j.seminoncol.2008.07.008|pmc=2702720|pmid=18929147}}</ref>
The group, with more than 7,500 experts worldwide, has nearly 100 active clinical-translational trials open at any given time. These trials include treatment for many types of childhood cancers, studies aimed at determining the underlying biology of these diseases, and trials involving new and emerging treatments, supportive care, and survivorship. More than 90% of 13,500 children and adolescents diagnosed with cancer each year in the United States are cared for at [http://applications.childrensoncologygroup.org/coglist/resources/cog.aspx Children’s Oncology Group member institutions].<ref name="O'Leary" />
== History == The cooperative group system for clinical research began in 1955 with a consortium focused on childhood cancer research.<ref name="O'Leary" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bleyer|first=WA|year=1997|title=The U.S. pediatric cancer clinical trials programmes: international implications and the way forward|journal=Eur J Cancer|volume=33|issue=9|pages=1439–1447|doi=10.1016/S0959-8049(97)00249-9|pmid=9337687}}</ref><ref name="Schilsky">{{cite journal|year=2006|title=A concise history of the cancer and leukemia group B|journal=Clin Cancer Res|volume=12|issue=11 Pt 2|pages=3553s-3555s|doi=10.1158/1078-0432.CCR-06-9000|pmid=16740784|vauthors=Schilsky RL, McIntyre OR, Holland JF, Frei E}}</ref> By the mid-1990s, there were nine groups funded by the NCI to conduct research in adults with cancer, and four focused on childhood cancer research. Two groups, the [[Children's Cancer Study Group]] (CCG) and the [[Pediatric Oncology Group]] (POG) studied a diverse array of childhood cancers, while two others, the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study Group (IRSG) and the [[National Wilms Tumor Study Group]] (NWTS) were specific for particular cancers. In 2000, the four pediatric groups merged to create the Children's Oncology Group.<ref name="O'Leary" /> Since then, its researchers have published well over one thousand research manuscripts in peer-reviewed scientific journals<ref name="O'Leary" /> COG has enrolled more children with cancer on clinical trials than any other organization in the world.
== Research studies == The group's research studies encompass hematologic malignancies, solid tumors, central nervous system tumors, and rare cancers. [[Hematologic malignancies]] include the most common childhood cancer, [[acute lymphoblastic leukemia]], as well as [[acute myeloid leukemia]], [[non-Hodgkin lymphoma]], and [[Hodgkin lymphoma]]. Pediatric [[solid tumors]] studied include [[neuroblastoma]], tumors of bone ([[Ewing sarcoma]], [[osteosarcoma]]), tumors of the kidney ([[Wilms' tumor]]), [[rhabdomyosarcoma]] and other [[soft tissue sarcomas]]. [[Brain tumors|Central nervous system (brain) tumors]] are the second most common form of childhood cancer. COG conducts research in children with [[medulloblastoma]], [[ependymoma]], [[brainstem gliomas]], low and high-grade [[gliomas]], and [[germ cell tumors]]. The large multi-site structure of COG also allows it to conduct research into very rare childhood cancer including [[retinoblastoma]], [[hepatoblastoma]], and other tumors.<ref name="O'Leary" />
In addition to disease specific research, COG conducts studies in developmental therapeutics (new cancer [[drug development]]), supportive care, [[epidemiology]], [[stem cell transplantation]], [[behavioral sciences]] and survivorship.<ref name=Reaman>{{cite journal|last=Reaman|first=GH|title=Pediatric cancer research from past successes through collaboration to future transdisciplinary research|journal=J Pediatr Oncol Nurs|year=2004|volume=21|pages=123–127|pmid=15296038|issue=3}}</ref>
==Funding== The COG is primarily funded by the NCI, the primary or Chair’s grant supports research operations and funds personnel at member institutions conducting research, and the statistics and data center grant supports these essential research functions.<ref name="Nass">{{cite journal|last=Nass|first=SJ|author2=Balogh E|author3=Mendelsohn J|year=2011|title=A National Cancer Clinical Trials Network: recommendations from the Institute of Medicine|journal=Am J Ther|volume=18|issue=5|pages=382–391|doi=10.1097/MJT.0b013e3181ff7e23|pmid=21326081|pmc=3135766}}</ref> Other key grants include the COG Phase 1 Consortium grant, supporting 21 COG institutions charged with early phase clinical trials,<ref name="CTEP Major Initiatives">{{cite web|url=http://ctep.cancer.gov/MajorInitiatives/Childrens_Oncology_Group.htm|title=Cancer Therapy Evaluation Program (CTEP) Major Initiatives|work=National Cancer Institute|publisher=NCI Cancer Therapy Evaluation Program}}</ref> and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20111014233313/http://dcp.cancer.gov/programs-resources/programs/ccop Community Cancer Oncology Program (CCOP)] grant.<ref name="Community Clinical Oncology program Research Base">{{cite web|url=http://fundedresearch.cancer.gov/search/details?action=abstract&grantNum=5U10CA095861-09&grantID=7844913&grtSCDC=FY%202010&absID=7844913&absSCDC=CURRENT|title=Community Clinical Oncology program Research Base|work=NCI Funded Research Portfolio}}</ref> These is additional funding from other granting agencies and from philanthropic sources (cog-foundation.org).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.childrensoncologygroup.org}} * [http://cog-foundation.org/ COG Foundation]
[[Category:Cancer organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Clinical trial organizations]] [[Category:Pediatrics in the United States|United States]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} [[File:Australian cigarette pack with health warning December 2012.jpg|thumb|250px|A sample package: a variety of warning packages are in use.]] '''Cigarette packets in Australia''' have undergone significant changes. Since 1 December 2012 all forms of branding [[logo]]s, colours, and promotional texts are banned from [[cigarette]] pack designs. In turn they were replaced with [[Olive (color)#Opaque Couch.C3.A9|drab dark brown]] packets ([[Pantone 448 C]])<ref>Rachel Wells (17 August 2012). [http://www.theage.com.au/national/does-this-colour-turn-you-off-20120816-24bf4.html Does this colour turn you off?]. ''The Age''. Retrieved on 7 December 2012.</ref> and graphic images of smoking-related images to try to reduce the smoking population of Australia to 10% by 2018 from 15% in 2012.
{{As of|2017|12}}, [[Australia]], [[France]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[Ireland]], [[Norway]], [[New Zealand]] and [[Hungary]] are the only countries to have plain packaging cigarette packs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Are electronic cigarettes legal in Australia?|url=http://www.ozvapour.com/are-electronic-cigarettes-legal-in-australia/|publisher=www.ozvapour.com|accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/mar/11/mps-pass-legislation-introduce-standardised-cigarette-packaging|title=MPs pass legislation to introduce standardised cigarette packaging|last=Perraudin|first=Frances|date=2015-03-11|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-05-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=La France adopte le paquet de cigarettes neutre|url=http://www.lesoir.be/1072520/article/actualite/fil-info/fil-info-monde/2015-12-17/france-adopte-paquet-cigarettes-neutre|accessdate=6 July 2016|work=Le Soir|date=18 December 2015|language=French}}</ref>
==History== In 1973, Australia's first [[Warning label|health warning]] on cigarette packages appeared with the simple message 'Warning—Smoking is a health hazard'.<ref>Scollo, Michelle & Haslam, Indra (2008). [http://www.tobaccoinaustralia.org.au/chapter-12-tobacco-products/attachment-12-1-health-warnings "Attachment 12.1 Health warnings"]. Tobacco in Australia. Cancer Council Victoria. Retrieved 30 November 2012.</ref> Since 1 March 2006, graphic images depicting the effects of smoking cigarettes have been required to be displayed on cigarette packets. Warnings must cover 30% of the front and 90% of the back of the box.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smoke-free.ca/warnings/Australia-warnings.htm|title=Australia – Warnings|work=www.smoke-free.ca|date=1 March 2006|accessdate=30 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121122110109/http://www.smoke-free.ca/warnings/Australia-warnings.htm|archivedate=22 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The 10% of the back not occupied by a warning is used for the message "Sale to underage persons prohibited".
Since 1 December 2012 all forms of branding logos, colours, and promotional texts are banned from cigarette pack designs. The requirement is for [[plain cigarette packaging]] showing only brand name and health warning messages. Australia was the first country to have plain packaging cigarette packs.<ref name="BBC News - Australia plans plain-packaging rule for cigarettes">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8650520.stm |title=Australia plans plain-packaging rule for cigarettes |publisher=BBC News |date=29 April 2010 |accessdate=30 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="Daily Mail - Australia PM bans cigarette logos as he orders world's first 'plain packaging' anti-smoking scheme">Richard Shears (28 April 2010). [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1269545/Australia-PM-bans-cigarette-logos-orders-worlds-plain-packaging-anti-smoking-scheme.html?ito=feeds-newsxml Australia PM bans cigarette logos as he orders world's first 'plain packaging' anti-smoking scheme]. Includes example image. Mail Online. Associated Newspapers. Retrieved on 7 December 2012.</ref> At the same time the plain packets were introduced, the size of the anti-smoking images became larger, so the two effects are difficult to separate.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gage |first1=Suzi |title=Standardised cigarette packaging is on its way, will it reduce smoking? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/sifting-the-evidence/2017/apr/27/standardised-cigarette-packaging-is-on-its-way-but-will-it-reduce-smoking |accessdate=7 July 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=27 April 2017 |language=en}}</ref>
Canada was the first country to use graphic pictures in conjunction with written warnings on cigarette packages, with the legislation coming in 2000.<ref>Haines-Saah, R. J., Bell, K., & Dennis, S. (2015). A [http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/pdfplus/10.2105/AJPH.2014.302362 Qualitative Content Analysis of Cigarette Health Warning Labels in Australia, Canada, the United Kingdom, and the United States]. American Journal of Public Health, 105(2), e61-9. doi:10.2105/AJPH.2014.302362</ref>
==Development around the world== {{Main article|Plain tobacco packaging}}
Following Australia's lead a number of other countries also require standardized packaging including [[France]] (applies to cigarettes sold after 1 January 2017), [[United Kingdom]] (21 May 2017), New Zealand (6 June 2018), [[Norway]] (1 July 2018), [[Ireland]] (30 September 2018) and [[Hungary]] (20 May 2019).
As a result of the enactment of the December 2015 plain tobacco packaging bill, on 1 January 2017 [[France]] became the second country in the world, after Australia, and the first in the [[European Union]] to require tobacco products to be sold in [[plain tobacco packaging|plain packaging]].<ref> [http://www.fctc.org/fca-news/opinion-pieces/1413-france-and-uk-join-australia-as-plain-packing-leaders France and the UK join Australia as plain packing leaders]</ref>
In March 2015, the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] voted 367–113 in favour of plain cigarette packaging in the [[United Kingdom]]. The sale of plain packs is compulsory since 21 May 2017.
==Warnings== {{main|Tobacco packaging warning messages}} For cigarette packets, warnings include: {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} * Smoking causes peripheral vascular disease * Smoking causes emphysema * Smoking causes mouth and throat cancer * Smoking clogs your arteries * Don't let children breathe your smoke {{col-break}} * Smoking – A leading cause of death * Quitting will improve your health * Smoking harms unborn babies * Smoking causes blindness * Smoking causes lung cancer {{col-break}} * Smoking causes heart disease * Smoking doubles your risk of stroke * Smoking is addictive * Tobacco smoke is toxic {{col-end}} With each warning is an accompanying graphic, and detailed information on the back of the packet. In addition, [[cigar]] and [[Shag (tobacco)|loose tobacco]] packets show other, slightly altered warnings. These warnings target the misconception that alternative, non-cigarette tobacco products are less harmful.
There have been calls to expand the range of warnings to reflect current research into the effects of smoking, such as impacts on fertility.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Tegan |title=Everyone knows smoking causes lung cancer, but what about infertility and arthritis? |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/health/2018-07-09/smoking-graphic-warning-label-refresh-to-improve-risk-knowledge/9947728 |accessdate=9 July 2018 |work=ABC News |date=9 July 2018 |language=en-AU}}</ref>
Australian cigarette packaging laws also prohibit the use of terms such as 'light', 'mild', 'extra mild', etc. The three major Australian tobacco manufacturers agreed to stop using these terms, after investigation of complaints of misleading and deceptive terms were made to the [[Australian Competition and Consumer Commission]] (ACCC) in 2005.<ref>Liberman, Jonathan (2008). [http://www.tobaccoinaustralia.org.au/chapter-16-litigation/16-2-other-litigation-involving-the-tobacco-indust "16.2.1 ACCC action on 'light' and 'mild' cigarettes"]. Tobacco in Australia. Cancer Council of Victoria. Retrieved 30 November 2012.</ref> This has assisted in counteracting the belief that some cigarette varieties are less harmful than others. To the same effect, while the carbon monoxide, nicotine and tar content of particular brands of cigarettes used to be mandated, the display and/or advertisement these figures is now prohibited under the government's "All Cigarettes are Toxic" campaign.
Although there has been no concrete proof as of 2014 that plain packaging has affected cigarette purchases in Australia,<ref>Davidson, S., & de Silva, A. (2014). The plain truth about plain packaging: An econometric analysis of the Australian 2011 tobacco plain packaging act. Agenda: A Journal of Policy Analysis and Reform, 21(1), 27-43. Young, J. M., Stacey, I., Dobbins, T. A., Dunlop, S., Dessaix, A. L., & Currow, D. C. (2014). Association between tobacco plain packaging and quitline calls: A population-based, [[interrupted time-series analysis]]. The Medical Journal of Australia, 200(1), 29-32. {{doi|10.5694/mja13.11070}}</ref> there has been a significant increase of calls to [http://www.quitnow.gov.au/ quitline] in some states<ref>Young, J., Stacey, I., Dobbins, T., Dunlop, S., Dessaix, A., & Currow, D. (2014). Association between tobacco plain packaging and Quitline calls: a population-based, interrupted time-series analysis. The Medical Journal of Australia, 200(1), 29-32. {{doi|10.5694/mja13.11070}}</ref> that would suggest plain packaging might encourage smokers to attempt or at least seek help with quitting smoking.
==See also==
{{Portal|Health|Australia}} *[[Plain tobacco packaging]] *[[Tobacco packaging warning messages]] *[[Health effects of tobacco]] *[[Tobacco advertising]] *[[Cigarette pack]] *[[Pantone 448C]] *[[Underage smoking in Australia]] {{-}}
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
