revision.text:
{{redirect|Joy of living|the 1961 film|The Joy of Living|other uses|Joy of life (disambiguation)}} {{Italic title|reason=.}} [[File:Eduard von Grützner Falstaff mit Handschuhen.jpg|thumb|[[Eduard von Grützner]]'s depiction of [[Falstaff]], a literary character well known for his ''joie de vivre'']] '''''Joie de vivre''''' ({{IPA-fr|ʒwa də vivʁ}}, ''joy of living'') is a [[List of French words and phrases used by English speakers|French phrase]] often used in English to express a cheerful enjoyment of life; an exultation of spirit. It "can be a joy of conversation, joy of eating, joy of anything one might do… And ''joie de vivre'' may be seen as a joy of everything, a comprehensive joy, a philosophy of life, a ''[[Weltanschauung]]''. Robert's ''Dictionnaire'' says joie is ''sentiment exaltant ressenti par toute la conscience'', that is, involves one's whole being."{{cite book |last=Shibles |first=Warren |year=1997 |title=Humor Reference Guide: A Comprehensive Classification and Analysis |location=Carbondale |publisher=Southern Illinois University Press |isbn=0-8093-2097-5 }} == Origins and development == Casual use of the phrase in French can be dated back at least as far as [[Fénelon]] in the late 17th century, but it was only brought into literary prominence in the 19th century, first by [[Jules Michelet|Michelet]] (1857) in his [[Pantheism|pantheistic]] work ''Insecte'', to contrast the passive life of plants with animal ''joie de vivre'',{{cite book |last1=Harrow |first1=Susan |last2=Unwin |first2=Timothy A |last3=Freeman |first3=Michael |year=2009 |title=Joie de vivre in French literature and culture : essays in honour of Michael Freeman |location=Amsterdam, NTH & New York, NY |publisher=[[Rodopi (publisher)|Rodopi Publishers]] |isbn=9789042028968 |oclc=430229593}}{{rp|300}} and then by [[Émile Zola]] in his [[La Joie de vivre|book of that name]] from 1883–84.{{rp|305}} Thereafter, it took on increasing weight as a mode of life, evolving at times almost into a [[secular religion]]{{rp|306}} in the early 20th century; and subsequently fed into [[Jacques Lacan|Lacanian]] emphasis on "a ''jouissance'' beyond the pleasure principle"{{cite book |last1=Lacan |first1=Jacques |author1-link=Jacques Lacan |last2=Miller |first2=Jacques-Alain |author2-link=Jacques-Alain Miller |last3=Sheridan |first3=Alan |author-link3=Alan Sheridan |year=1994 |title=The four fundamental concepts of psycho-analysis |location=London, UK |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |isbn=9780140242782 |oclc=33725110 |page=184}}
Later online version of {{cite book |title=The four fundamental concepts of psycho-analysis |year=2004 |location=London, UK & New York, NY |publisher=Karnac |id={{OCLC|733841387|729166946}} |subscription=yes}} in the latter half of the century – a time when its emphasis on enthusiasm, energy and spontaneity gave it a global prominence with the rise of [[hippie]] culture.{{cite book |last1=Andrews |first1=Cecile |year=2006 |title=Slow is beautiful : new visions of community, leisure and joie de vivre |location=Gabriola Island, BC, Canada |publisher=[[Douglas & McIntyre|New Society Publishers]] |page=96 |isbn=9781550924145 |id={{OCLC|471124890|810539385}}}} == Psychology == 20th-century proponents of [[self-actualization]] such as [[Abraham Maslow]] or [[Carl Rogers]] saw, as one of the by-products, the rediscovery of what the latter called "the quiet joy in being one's self...a spontaneous relaxed enjoyment, a primitive ''joie de vivre''".{{cite book |last1=Rogers |first1=Carl R |author1-link=Carl R Rogers |year=1961 |title=On becoming a person : a therapist's view of psychotherapy |location=Boston, MA, USA |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Company]] |pages=87–88 |isbn=9780395084090 |oclc=172718}}
Later online versions of {{cite book |title=On becoming a person : a therapist's view of psychotherapy. |id={{OCLC|782873749|783585017|856932797|858970706}} |subscription=yes}}
{{Google books|FTEPV9IYQ5EC|On Becoming a Person: A Therapist's View of Psychotherapy}} ''Joie de vivre'' has also been linked to [[D. W. Winnicott]]'s concept of a sense of play, and of access to the [[true self]].{{cite book |last1=Lamb |first1=Charles |author1-link=Charles Lamb |year=1985 |editor1-last=Phillips |editor1-first=Adam |editor1-link=Adam Phillips (psychologist) |title=Selected prose |location=Harmondsworth, Middlesex, UK & New York, NY |publisher=[[Penguin classics]] |page=446 |isbn=9780140432381 |oclc=680112630}} == Adaptations == It is usually referenced in its standard French form, but various corruptions are observed such as ''joie de vie'', which would translate to "joy of life".{{cite web |url=http://www.wayfair.com/Art-4-Kids-Joie-de-Vie-Poodle-Dog-Wall-Art-21408-AFK1292.html |title=Joie de Vie Poodle Dog Wall Art |accessdate=2013-11-16 |website=wayfair.com}} The [[Matisse]] painting ''[[Le bonheur de vivre]]'' translates as, "The Happiness of Life". == See also == {{wiktionary}} {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| *''[[Bon viveur]]'' *''[[Carpe diem]]'' *''[[Élan vital]]'' *[[Epicurus]] *[[Flow (psychology)]] *[[Happiness]] *[[Joy]] *[[Quality of life]] *[[François Rabelais]] }} ==References== {{reflist|2|}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book |first=William |last=Schutz |authorlink=William Schutz |title=Joy: Expanding Human Awareness |year=1973 |location= New York, NY |publisher=[[Ballantine Books]] |isbn=9780345274595 |oclc=3756811}} *{{cite book |last1=Csikszentmihalyi |first1=Mihaly |year=1991 |title=Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v2AVz3gf-F4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=oclc473801272&cd=1#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=New York, NY |publisher=[[Harper Perennial]] |isbn=9780060920432 |oclc=473801272 |accessdate=2013-11-16 |authorlink1=Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Joie De Vivre}} [[Category:French words and phrases]] [[Category:Happiness]]

revision.comment: whoa
revision.text:
'''Katharina Lohrenz Schellenberg''' (1870 - January 1, 1945) was an [[United States|American]] [[Mennonite]] medical missionary of [[Russia]]n birth.
Schellenberg was born in the village of Tiegerweide, at the time in South Russia, today in [[Ukraine]]; it is part of the [[Molotschna]] Mennonite colony. Her parents were Abraham and Katharina Lohrenz Schellenberg, with whom she immigrated to the [[United States]] in 1879, settling in Kansas.<ref name="LindleyStebner2008">{{cite book|author1=Susan Hill Lindley|author2=Eleanor J. Stebner|title=The Westminster Handbook to Women in American Religious History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R4hLAtDBHskC&pg=PA134|year=2008|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|isbn=978-0-664-22454-7|page=193}}</ref> When she was fourteen, her mother died. At nineteen, she made her first commitment to Christ, joining the Mennonite congregation in [[Buhler, Kansas|Buhler]], [[Kansas]].<ref name="mbhistory.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.mbhistory.org/profiles/schell.en.html|title=MBHC: Profiles: Katharina Schellenberg|website=www.mbhistory.org|accessdate=25 August 2018}}</ref> Schellenberg studied medicine at the Deaconess Hospital in [[Cleveland]], an undertook further study at the [[Medical Institute of Homeopathic Medicine]] in [[Kansas City, Kansas|Kansas City]], [[Kansas]]; she was the first woman among North American Mennonites to become a doctor, and became the denomination's first medical missionary in [[India]] when she traveled to that country in 1907.<ref name="LindleyStebner2008"/> She learned to speak [[Telugu language|Telugu]] as part of her preparations. Early in her career she worked in various locations, from Hughestown as far south as the [[Tungabhadra River]]; the mission built a hospital at [[Nagarkurnool]] in 1912.<ref name="Anderson1999">{{cite book|author=Gerald H. Anderson|title=Biographical Dictionary of Christian Missions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oQ8BFk9K0ToC&pg=PA596|year=1999|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0-8028-4680-8|pages=596–}}</ref> The 1928 completion of another hospital, in [[Shamshabad]], meant that city became her home base. Many of her patients were [[Islam|Muslim]] women who could not be seen by a male doctor. Schellenberg died suddenly in India, and is buried in the St. George Cemetery in [[Hyderabad]].<ref name="mbhistory.org"/> An archive of photographs related to her career in India is held at the Mennonite Library & Archives at [[Fresno Pacific University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archives.mhsc.ca/katharina-schellenberg-collection|title=Katharina Schellenberg Collection - Mennonite Archival Image Database|website=archives.mhsc.ca|accessdate=25 August 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schellenberg, Katharina}}
[[Category:1870 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:American Mennonites]] [[Category:People from Zaporizhia Oblast]] [[Category:People from Reno County, Kansas]] [[Category:Imperial Russian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American women physicians]] [[Category:20th-century American physicians]] [[Category:Mennonite missionaries]] [[Category:Female Christian missionaries]] [[Category:Medical missionaries]] [[Category:American expatriates in India]]

page.title: List of people who have walked across the United States

revision.text:
<!-- ###################################################################################################################################### ###################################################################################################################################### #### ARE YOU HERE TO ADD YOURSELF OR SOMEONE ELSE TO THIS LIST? #### #### #### #### In that case, very well done if you are actually the person who managed to perform this feat! However, having walked the #### #### distance on its own is not enough for encyclopedic inclusion. Only list a person if there is a specific claim to importance, #### #### such as: #### #### 1) Being the first or fastest to walk a specific distance. This must be backed up by a reliable source. #### #### 2) Already having a separate biographical article on Wikipedia. #### #### 3) Having been mentioned in newspapers or other reliable sources beyond the completion of the walk for #### #### other reasons, in which case criterion #2 is likely to apply. #### #### #### #### Thanks in advance for your understanding and cooperation. #### ###################################################################################################################################### ###################################################################################################################################### ---> {{dynamic list}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2016}}
This is a '''list of people who have walked across the United States''' from the [[East Coast of the United States|east coast]] to the [[West Coast of the United States|west coast]] or vice versa. Walking or running across the [[United States]] has long been pursued as a way to bring publicity to social causes.
==Richard Llew Evans== [[Richard Llew Evans]] departed [[Tybee Island]], Georgia, at 8:30 AM, November 24, 2017, and arrived at Imperial beach, [[San Diego]], on January 31, 2018, at 12:45 PM.<ref>http://walk4parkinsons.org</ref> Evans appears to have set the record for walking coast to coast (67 days). Evans has Parkinson's disease and walked an average of 1.5 marathons per day, every day without a break. Evans was real-time trackable throughout his walk via Google location sharing and had different people walking with him in each state. Evans raised over $120,000 for the Michael J. Fox foundation and is writing a book about the connections he made along the way.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.today.com/video/meet-the-man-who-s-walking-2-500-miles-to-fight-parkinson-s-disease-1111453251932|title=Meet the man who’s walking 2,500 miles to fight Parkinson’s disease|website=TODAY.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2018/02/05/wilmette-man-completes-walk-across-us-parkinson-s-disease|title=Wilmette Man Completes Walk Across US for Parkinson’s Disease|website=wttw.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/communities/south-county/sd-se-parkinsons-walk-20180131-story.html|title=Man with Parkinson's disease finishes cross-country walk in Imperial Beach|first=David|last=Hernandez|website=sandiegouniontribune.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kusi.com/uncorked-adventures-walk-across-america/|title=Uncorked Adventures: Walk Across America|date=January 31, 2018|website=kusi.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecwsandiego.com/story/37399074/walking-forparkingsonsfrom-sea-to-shining-sea|title=Walking for Parkinson's from sea to shining sea|website=thecwsandiego.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yumasun.com/bill-bucklew/image_591068a8-0320-11e8-9822-0799944b66df.html|title=Bill Bucklew|first=Photo by Randy Hoeft/Yuma|last=Sun|website=yumasun.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcsun-news.com/story/news/2018/01/12/bill-bucklew-wont-let-parkinsons-diagnosis-stop-him-walking-across-country/1030675001/|title=Bill Bucklew won't let Parkinson's diagnosis stop him from walking across the country|website=lcsun-news.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.news-journal.com/videos/2017/dec/18/1245/|title=Bill Bucklew - Walk for Parkinson's - Longview News-Journal|website=www.news-journal.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
==[[Rory Hill]]== [[Bradford Lyttle]], an organizer with the [[Committee for Non-Violent Action]], and several others walked from [[San Francisco]] to [[New York City]], and then through parts of Europe to [[Moscow]], Russia, from December 1960 until late 1961. The action was called the [[San Francisco to Moscow March]] for Peace. Several participants, including Lyttle, walked the entire distance. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1961/10/04/archives/peace-marchers-reach-red-square-but-soviet-prohibits-speeches-peace.html|title=Peace Marchers Reach Red Square But Soviet Prohibits Speeches - UPI/The New York Times|website=www.nytimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/40109166?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents|title=Lifting the Iron Curtain: The Peace March to Moscow of 1960-1961 - The International History Review|website=www.jstor.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://nvdatabase.swarthmore.edu/content/anti-war-activists-march-moscow-peace-1960-1961|title=Anti-war activists march to Moscow for peace, 1960-1961 - Global Nonviolent Action Database, Swarthmore College|website=nvdatabase.swarthmore.edu}}</ref>
==Dale James Outhouse, Adele Kushner, Kevin James Shay== These participants of A [[Walk of the People – A Pilgrimage for Life]] walked across the United States in 1984 as part of the action that called for global nuclear disarmament and better relations between the U.S. and former [[Soviet Union]]. The march started at [[Point Conception]], Calif., and went through Texas and the Deep South to [[New York City]]. Several others, including Andy Rector, walked significant portions across the U.S. and continued in Europe to [[Moscow]], Russia, in 1985. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.apnews.com/7ba3f8625c2931f93edb4a112db1c95e|title=U.S. Peace Activists Denied East German Visas - Associated Press, Sept. 13, 1985|website=www.apnews.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.swarthmore.edu/library/peace/peacewebsite/scpcWebsite/Documents/NewBooks2011-2012.html|title=New Books, Periodicals, and Electronic Media in the Swarthmore College Peace Collection - Swarthmore College|website=www.swarthmore.edu}}</ref>
==[[Ed Fallon]], Miriam Kashia, Mackenzie McDonald Wilkins, Jeffrey Czerwiec, Steve Martin== These were the five participants in the [[Great March for Climate Action]] who completed every step of the 3,100-mile walk from [[Los Angeles]], California, to [[Washington, D.C.]] between March 1 and November 1, 2014. Halfway through the March, Steve Martin left the main body of marchers to walk solo to New York, arriving there on September 21 as an emissary from the Great March for Climate Action to the [[People's Climate March]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/2014/10/20/climate-march/17603915/|title=Climate marchers have sore feet, but feel good about work|website=desmoinesregister.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Mark Baumer== [[Mark Baumer]] walked across the USA in 81 days. He was killed in 2017 while attempting a second walk barefoot.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/harriet/2017/08/providence-journal-remembers-mark-baumer |title=Providence Journal Remembers Poet Mark Baumer |author=Harriett Staff, Darcie Dennigan |date=August 11, 2017}}</ref>
==Michael Ross & George Crawford== Michael Ross, 18, from Manchester, CT, walked from Danbury, CT to Huntington Beach, CA. This walk took 297 days and was in an effort to raise funds and awareness for the Livestrong Foundation. Over $13,000 was raised. Michael was accompanied by his childhood friend, George Crawford. Most days both Michael and George were welcomed into the homes of kind people who would make dinner and give them a place to sleep. They could not believe the amount of hospitality they received. The walk started April 2013 and ended February 2014. <ref>https://triblive.com/neighborhoods/yourallekiskivalley/yourallekiskivalleymore/5506334-74/ross-crawford-livestrong</ref><ref>https://www.facebook.com/walkingforacure2013/</ref>
==Philip Cihiwsky== Phil Cihiwsky, 59, from Loveland, Colorado, walked from San Diego, California, to York Harbor, Maine, starting his walk on March 4 and completing it on October 4, 2013. He walked 3300 miles, crossing 15 states in 7 months while raising awareness about food insecurity issues among older adults for [[Meals On Wheels]] and encouraging the people he met along the way to support home-delivered meal programs in their own communities.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/articles/20131005-NEWS-310050318 |work=Seacoastonline |title=Man walks across country for Meals on Wheels |author=Susan Morse |date=October 5, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2013/mar/04/volunteer-will-walk-and-wheel-3200-miles-support-m/ |work=KPBS News |title=Volunteer Will Walk And Wheel 3,200 Miles To Support Meals On Wheels |author=Dwane Brown |date=March 4, 2013}}</ref>
==Elliott Lannen and Graeme Lithgow== Elliott Lannen and Graeme Jeffrey Lithgow walked from [[San Francisco]], California, to St. Augustine, Florida, from 2013 to 2014. The party began with three members, but Julio Lopez abandoned the project after traversing the California coast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.staugustine.com/news/local-news/2014-06-08/sea-shining-sea|title=Video: From sea to shining sea|first=BOB|last=TIS|website=staugustine.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Helga and Clara Estby== [[Helga Estby]], a 36-year-old from [[Spokane, Washington]], and her 18-year-old daughter Clara walked from Spokane to [[New York City]] in 1896, setting off on May 5, 1896, passing through 14 states along the way, and arriving at the latter on [[Christmas Eve]]. She did so in response to a $10,000 challenge from a sponsor given to any woman who would walk across the United States. She brought with her a compass, red-pepper spray, a revolver, and a curling iron. She wanted the money in order to save her family's {{convert|160|acre|ha|adj=on}} farm. She did not receive it.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Book Honors Pair's Courageous, Forgotten Walk Across America |date=June 1, 2003 |author=Christy Karras|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|pages=D6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Get on the road with a good book |author=Margo Hammond|date=June 23, 2006 |work=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |url=http://sptimes.com./2006/07/23/Books/Get_on_the_road_with_.shtml}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=The Nation: Women Get No Mileage From Cross-Country Trek|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Chris Rodkey|date=July 13, 2003 |pages=A.27}}</ref>
==Louis Michael Figueroa== In 1982, Louis Michael Figueroa, age 16, became the fastest and youngest person (according to some sources)<ref name="ContraCosta" /> to run across the United States, covering the route from [[New Brunswick, NJ]] to [[San Francisco]] in 60 days to fulfill a promise to a friend who was dying of bone cancer.<ref name="Figueroa1982" />
In 1996–1997 he walked from [[Bangor, ME]] to [[San Diego, CA]] for local AIDS networks in memory of his brother Jimmy, who died of the disease. The walk was plagued by delays due to Figueroa's battle with Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia.<ref name="Figueroa1982" />
In 2005, he began a walk around the United States for victims of child abuse. Figueroa walked for six months and covered {{convert|6,437|mi|km}} of the {{convert|12,070|mi|km}}.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Figueroa Video Interview on WTOC-TV of Savannah, Georgia|url=http://www.gwdaz.com/figueroa.wmv}}</ref>
On June 4, 2010, Figueroa left from where he previously stopped, {{convert|6.43|mi|km}} west of Somerset, PA and arrived in Tucson on January 15, 2011.<ref name="ContraCosta">{{Cite news|url=http://www.contracostatimes.com/ci_16697093 |date=November 23, 2010 |title=Long-distance walker on journey to protect children|work=[[Contra Costa Times]]}}</ref><ref name="Figueroa1982">{{Cite news|url=http://wc.arizona.edu/papers/98/68/01_4.html |date=November 30, 2004 |title=Man to walk across U.S. for children's rights|work=[[Arizona Daily Wildcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.brookfieldnow.com/news/97873589.html |date=July 6, 2010 |title=The real 'Forrest Gump' stopped by police in Elm Grove|work=[[BrookfieldNow]]}}</ref>{{update after|2010|12|31|df=mdy}}
==Aaron Huey== [[Aaron Huey]], age 26, left Encinitas, California, on January 22, 2002 and arrived in New York City 3,349 miles and 154 days later on June 25. His only travel companion was his dog Cosmo. He did not carry a cell phone and had no support team.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/pacificnw/2005/0424/cover.html |date=April 24, 2005 |title=Walking Across America |work=[[The Seattle Times Sunday Magazine]]}}</ref> Huey covered the why and how in his 2010 [[Annenberg Foundation]] lecture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.annenbergspaceforphotography.org/events/iris_nights_past_ee_huey.asp|title=Events - Annenberg Space for Photography|website=Annenberg Space for Photography|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref> and Huey also wrote journals of his travels along the way.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aaronhuey.com/walk/pages/aaronhuey/walk_index.html|title=Aaron Huey: Photographer, Argonaut, Rock Star|website=www.aaronhuey.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Pete Kostelnick== In October 2016, [[Pete Kostelnick]], age 29, set the world record for fastest run across America; he ran the 3,067 miles from [[San Francisco City Hall|San Francisco’s City Hall]] to [[New York City Hall|New York’s City Hall]] in 42 days, 6 hours, 30 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |last=Fox |first=Kit |url=http://www.runnersworld.com/ultrarunning/ultrarunner-pete-kostelnick-smashes-record-for-run-across-us |title=Ultrarunner Pete Kostelnick Smashes Record for Run Across U.S |work=[[Runner's World]] |date=October 24, 2016 |access-date=October 25, 2016}}</ref>
==Barbara Moore== [[Barbara Moore (vegetarian)|Barbara Moore]] (1903–1977),<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/05/15/archives/dr-barbara-moore-who-walked-across-us-is-dead-at-73.html?sq=dr.+barbara+moore+walk&scp=6&st=p |work=New York Times | title=Dr. Barbara Moore, Who Walked Across U.S., Is Dead at 73 |date=May 15, 1977 |access-date=March 26, 2008}}</ref> a Russian-born health enthusiast, walked 3,387 miles from [[San Francisco]] to [[New York City]] in 85 days in 1960, departing on April 13 and arriving on July 6.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/opinion/columnists/president-capped-visit-with-barbecue/article_89aaf08d-1bcf-5de0-a8a5-267785718e3d.html |title= This week in local history|author=Bill Clark |date=July 1, 2010|access-date=January 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1960/04/14/page/43/article/interview-withfout-a-halt |publisher=Chicago Tribune |title= Interview without a halt|date=April 14, 1960|access-date=January 16, 2016}}</ref>
==Richard H. Noble== From March 12, 2011 through June 9, 2012, Richard Noble, a gay rights activist, walked with a [[rainbow flag]] from San Francisco to Jacksonville Beach, Florida.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtdemocrat.com/news/corsscountry-hiker-promotes-gay-rights-amendmentts|title=Crosscountry hiker promotes gay rights amendments|work=Mountain Democrat}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/politics/commentary/2012/01/24/oped-sleeping-praying-and-walking-across-america-equality|title=OpEd Sleeping Praying and Walking Across America for Equality|author=Advocate Contributors|work=Advocate.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-duran/richard-noble-lgbt-rights_b_1665711.html|title=Richard Noble, a Man You Should Know|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref>
==James Harry Pierce== James Harry Pierce, a 46-year-old writer, costumer, and street performer,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jamesacrossamerica.blogspot.com/2011/05/day-one-baby-steps.html|title=Walking Across America -- 2011: Day One, Baby Steps|first=James|last=Pierce|date=May 29, 2011|website=jamesacrossamerica.blogspot.com|accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref> began his walk across the United States on May 30, 2011 just south of [[Seattle, Washington]], passed through [[Crestview, Florida]] on December 24, 2011,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ufdcimages.uflib.ufl.edu/UF/00/02/84/11/00693/12-24-2011.pdf |date=December 24, 2011 |title=Walking across America|work=[[CrestView News Bulletin page A5]]}}</ref> and continued on to [[Key West, Florida]], where he settled on February 7, 2012 and now performs nightly on [[Duval Street]] dressed as [[Darth Vader]] playing the [[banjo]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://keysnews.com/node/67134|date=May 31, 2015 |title=Duval performers need a license to thrill|work=[[KeysNews.com]]}}</ref>
==Peace Pilgrim== [[Peace Pilgrim]], née Mildred Lisette Norman (July 18, 1908 – July 7, 1981), was an American pacifist, vegetarian, and peace activist. Starting on January 1, 1953, she walked across the United States for 28 years until her death in 1981.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/2013/01/01/168346591/peace-pilgrims-28-year-walk-for-a-meaningful-way-of-life|title=Peace Pilgrim's 28-Year Walk For 'A Meaningful Way Of Life'|work=NPR|date=January 1, 2013 |access-date=January 1, 2013}}</ref> She had no organizational backing, carried no money, and would not even ask for food or shelter. When she began her pilgrimage she had taken a vow to "remain a wanderer until mankind has learned the way of peace, walking until given shelter and fasting until given food." At the time of her death, she was crossing the United States for the seventh time.
==Granny D== [[Granny D]] (née Doris Haddock, January 24, 1910 – March 9, 2010) achieved international fame in February 2000 when, at age 90, she completed her walk across the U.S. to support [[campaign finance reform]]. A resident of [[Dublin, New Hampshire]], Granny D started the walk January 1, 1999, shortly before her 89th birthday in [[Pasadena, California]] amid the [[Rose Parade]] festivities. Despite being hospitalized for pneumonia after walking across the Mojave Desert, Granny D completed her walk on [[Leap Day]] of the following year, more than 400 days later, having traversed over 3200 miles across nine states (California, Arizona, New Mexico, Texas, Arkansas, Tennessee, Kentucky, West Virginia, and Maryland). She had to travel much of the last 100 miles on cross-country skis due to a snowstorm that made walking impossible.<ref name="GrannyD 2001">GrannyD: Walking Across America in my 90th Year, Doris Haddock and Dennis Burke, 2001,Villard, NY</ref> Before her life was over, she wrote about her walk in two books. The first was co-authored by Dorris Haddock (Granny D) and Dennis Burke, "Granny D: Walking Across America in my 90th Year."<ref name="GrannyD 2001"/> She chronicled her expedition and reasons for undertaking it in an autobiography entitled "You're Never Too Old to Raise a Little Hell" published in 2003. The following year, at age 94, she ran as Democratic candidate against [[Judd Gregg]] in the New Hampshire senate race, but was soundly defeated. She died shortly after turning 100, on March 9, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/12/us/12haddock.html|title=Doris Haddock, Cross-Country Walker, Dies at 100|first=Dennis|last=Hevesi|date=March 11, 2010|publisher=|access-date=February 6, 2018|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
==Chad Sigmon== Chad Sigmon was 38 years old when he ran across America starting April 1, 2013, from Jacksonville, Florida, and ending August 1 in San Diego, California. He ran to help end mental health stigma. He averaged around 22 miles a day for a total of 2,650 miles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theet.com/news/article_eec5b6e0-9d9b-11e2-b8c3-001a4bcf887a.html|title=Local Chad Sigmon travels coast to coast raising mental health awareness|first=From Staff|last=Reports|website=theet.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.willcoxrangenews.com/news/article_202eea56-ee6b-11e2-af8d-001a4bcf887a.html|title=Increasing mental health awareness|first=Ainslee S. Wittig Arizona Range|last=News|website=willcoxrangenews.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Katie Visco== From March 29 through December 29, 2009, Pave Your Lane's founder, Katie Visco, ran across America, from [[Boston]] to San Diego to publicize this campaign. At age 24, Visco became the second-youngest and 13th woman overall to run from coast to coast.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Katie Visco Completes Run Across America|author=Mario Fraioli|work=[[Running Competitor]]|date=December 29, 2009 |url=http://running.competitor.com/2009/12/news/katie-visco-completes-run-across-america_7514}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paveyourlane.com/page/katies-run-across-america-2009|title=dfltweb1.onamae.com – このドメインはお名前.comで取得されています。|website=www.paveyourlane.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Bob Wieland== [[Bob Wieland]] is a Vietnam War veteran who lost his legs to a mortar mine in 1969. He "ran" across America on his hands, taking three years, eight months, and six days to travel from coast to coast and raise money for Vietnam war veterans.<ref name= "Rote-Pettigrew p. 289">{{cite book |ref=harv|last=Rote|first=Kyle |last2=Pettigrew|first2=Joe | title = Living Life in the Zone: A 40-Day Spiritual Gameplan for Men|edition=2009|year=2009| publisher = Thomas Nelson Inc| isbn= 978-0-8499-4652-3| page=289}}</ref>
==Zachary Bonner== [[Zachary Bonner]] is a homeless youth advocate. He started a non profit when he was 6 years old called the Little Red Wagon Foundation. At age 8 after seeing a documentary on a woman named [[Peace Pilgrim]] he decided to walk from his home in [[Tampa, Florida]] to the state Capitol [[Tallahassee]]. The following year at age 9 he continued his walk to [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]] and that summer at age 11 he walked from Atlanta to [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="NBCZach">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/30644308/ns/us_news-giving/t/fla-boy-walking-dc-homeless-kids/#.U6JROJSwLOg|title=Fla. boy walking to D.C. for homeless kids|work=[[NBCNews.com]]|accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref> He vowed to become the youngest to walk Coast to Coast and at age 12 completed that mission by walking from [[Jacksonville Beach]] to the [[Santa Monica Pier]]. During his walks he used media attention to raise awareness to homeless youth and highlighted many programs working to help these kids.<ref name="Marshall">{{cite web|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/05/20/2206009/12-year-old-florida-boy-takes.html|title=12-year-old Florida boy takes Six Flags break during 2,500-mile walk | Today's Buzz|last=Marshall|first=Joyce|date=May 21, 2010|work=[[Star Telegram]] |accessdate=June 19, 2014}}</ref> The journey took Zach 7 months to complete.
==Joe "Tiger" Patrick II== [[Joe "Tiger" Patrick II]] is a [[Peace Dale, Rhode Island|Peace Dale]], [[Rhode Island]], Army veteran. After volunteering at [[World Trade Center site|Ground Zero]] for three weeks he decided he wanted to do something to bring awareness to the men and women who died as a result of the events during the [[September 11 attacks|9/11 attacks]], and those who have died while serving in the military for the United States of America.<ref name=gazette>{{cite news|last=Prater|first=Erin|title=A war veteran, a flag and a mission |url=http://gazette.com/a-war-veteran-a-flag-and-a-mission/article/1502508 |access-date=July 14, 2013 |newspaper=The Gazette |date=June 19, 2013}}</ref><ref name=heraldmail>{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Roxann|title=Rhode Island man treks through Chambersburg on way to ground zero |url=http://articles.herald-mail.com/2011-08-22/news/29917047_1_rhode-island-man-dog-tags-turnout-coat |access-date=July 19, 2013 |newspaper=The Herald|date=August 22, 2011}}</ref> He committed to walking for the cause. He completed a memorial walk in 2011 and on his second walk in 2013 he walked approximately 3,000 miles across the United States beginning in April 2013 in the City of Coronado, California and ending in Washington D.C. in October 2013.<ref name=citycoronado>{{cite web |url=http://www.coronado.ca.us/egov/documents/1366996416_56322.pdf |title=Faces of Our Fallen |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |website=The City of Coronado California |publisher=City of Coronado, California |access-date=July 14, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004213111/http://www.coronado.ca.us/egov/documents/1366996416_56322.pdf |archivedate=October 4, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=imperialpress>{{cite news |last=Rangel |first=Alexis|title=One man's extraordinary walk across America |url=http://www.ivpressonline.com/news/ivp-one-mans-extraordinary-walk-across-america-20130507,0,7804536.story|accessdate=July 15, 2013 |newspaper=Imperial Valley Press News|date=May 7, 2013}}</ref> During this walk he carried a memorial panel that he created on canvas, which displayed the faces of over 6600 color images of U.S. service members, and weighed over 50 pounds. He also carried an American flag and a bat used by Boston Red Sox second baseman [[Dustin Pedroia]].
==Walter O. McGill III== [[Creation Seventh Day Adventist Church#Petitions and walk across America|Walter McGill]], also known as Pastor "Chick" McGill,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sbsun.com/general-news/20150421/man-walking-across-america-comes-through-inland-empire-san-gabriel-valley |title=Man walking across America comes through Inland Empire, San Gabriel Valley |access-date=May 3, 2015}}</ref> the "Freedom Walker"<ref name = "fw">{{cite web | url=http://www.rivervalleyleader.com/news/local/article_a7830a64-3f5f-11e4-b806-0017a43b2370.html |title="Freedom-Walker" Carries Nation’s Flag Cross-country |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref> and the "Cross Country Flagman,"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mohavedailynews.com/news/going-for-a-long-walk-national-prayer-trek-brings-pastor/article_ac3c0bb0-cc76-11e4-97be-fbfac9f92cd6.html |title=Going for a long walk: National prayer trek brings pastor through Bullhead City |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref> a 69-year-old pastor of the [[Creation Seventh Day Adventist Church]] and [[Vietnam War]] era [[veteran]], began to walk across the United States on April 23, 2014- at [[Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina]].<ref>''Roanoke Beacon'', April 23, 2014. "Pastor's trek across America is God's idea"</ref><ref>''The Coastland Times'', April 20, 2014. "Cross country walk to start in Kill Devil Hills"</ref> He completed his journey on April 29, 2015 at the [[Santa Monica Pier]] in [[Santa Monica, California]] after traveling a route of over 3,200 miles,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abc7.com/society/veteran-finishes-cross-country-walk-carrying-american-flag/691656/ |title=69-Year-Old Veteran Finishes Cross Country Walk Carrying American Flag |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://zachnews.wordpress.com/2015/04/29/news-update-santa-monica-ca-man-walking-coast-to-coast-reached-his-final-destination-at-santa-monica-pier/ |title=News Update!! Santa Monica, CA: Man walking coast to coast reached his final destination at Santa Monica Pier| access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref> and carrying the [[Flag of the United States|United States flag]] by hand the entire way, the first such documented case.<ref name="fw"/><ref name = "sm">{{cite web | url=http://www.smmirror.com/articles/News/Veteran-To-Complete-Coast-To-Coast-Walk-At-Santa-Monica-Pier-Wednesday/43197 |title=Veteran To Complete Coast-To-Coast Walk At Santa Monica Pier Wednesday |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref> On July 12, 2015 he was honored at [[Dodger Stadium]] for the completion of the walk prior to a [[baseball]] game between the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] and the [[Milwaukee Brewers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lucernevalleyleader.com/veteran-honored-dodgers-stadium |title=Veteran honored at Dodgers Stadium |access-date=September 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenewsobserver.com/view/full_story_free/26824673/article-McGill-completes-walk-across-America?instance=lead_story |title=McGill completes walk across America |access-date=September 12, 2015}}</ref>
McGill's websites promoting the walk, walkingcoast2coast and walkthewalknow.com, indicate an extensive list of causes for which he made the journey, including: [[civil liberties]], [[human rights]], national integrity, the restoration of individual and corporate self-respect, support for traditional [[family values]], [[liberty of conscience]] for all citizens, the defense of [[United States Constitution|constitutional principles]], the review and appreciation of American heritage, care for the poor and homeless, the promotion of [[Naturopathy|natural health]] practices, employment of the [[Golden Rule]] in daily living, and a spiritual awakening for the healing of the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://walkthewalknow.com/ |title=walkthewalknow.com}}</ref> Along the way he saluted passing motorists and pedestrians,<ref name="fw"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://courier-tribune.com/news/saluting-america |title=Saluting America |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref> received certificates of appreciation at the [[Inland Empire]] and [[San Gabriel Valley]], and left non-sectarian 40-day prayer guides for city and county officials.<ref name="sm"/><ref name = "esc">{{cite web |url=http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2015/04/29/tenn-pastor-to-end-cross-country-prayer-walk-at-santa-monica-pier/ |title=Tenn. Pastor To End Cross-Country ‘Prayer Walk’ At Santa Monica Pier |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref> He was provided with a [[police escort]] part of the way along his walk in Tennessee and Georgia,<ref name="esc"/> and was awarded a "Day of Recognition" in his home state of Tennessee by Governor [[Bill Haslam]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://yahourrighteousness.net/coast2coast/TN_DayRec.jpg |title=Day of Recognition Certificate |access-date=May 3, 2015}}</ref>
During the portion of the journey through [[Prescott, Arizona]] he dedicated ten miles of his walk to [[Kayla Mueller]], who was captured by [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] and killed earlier in 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.abc15.com/news/region-northern-az/prescott/tennessee-pastor-honors-kayla-mueller |title=Tennessee pastor honors Kayla Mueller |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref>
In his closing statements, McGill said, "To be the first veteran to carry [[Flag of the United States|Old Glory]] from sea to shining sea has been a great aspiration of mine, and I'm praying this flag will be enshrined at the [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian Institute]] [sic]."<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DimB12Sde-M|title=VERY MOVING: 69 YEAR OLD PASTOR WALKS ACROSS AMERICA. REACHES PACIFIC OCEAN |access-date=May 2, 2015}}</ref>
==Arthur Hitchcock== Arthur Hitchcock is a documentary-editorial photographer who, at age 19, walked from [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], [[California]] to [[Augusta, Maine|Augusta]], [[Maine]] between May 11 and November 2, 2011. He walked approximately {{convert|4100|mi|km|0}}, crossing through 17 states in 175 days. Hitchcock walked to raise funds for breast cancer research and aid to assist families dealing with the cost of hospital bills and treatments. He walked to honor his deceased parents, Janet and Mike Hitchcock. His mother died from [[ductal carcinoma]] a few months before the trip. The majority of his route included major highways (it's illegal to walk on most major highways). He was led by a support vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/38480783|title=Hitchcock Walks|first=Required|last=Reading|date=March 14, 2012|publisher=|access-date=February 6, 2018|via=Vimeo}}</ref>
==John Ball== Retired U.S. Air Force Colonel John Ball, aka “The Walking Aggie,” walked coast-to-coast across America from March 1, 2015<ref>{{cite AV media| url=http://www.lajollalight.com/news/2015/feb/24/texas-man-walk-coast-to-coast-starting-in-la-jolla/ | title=Walker, Texas Aggie: Man to walk coast to coast, starting in La Jolla |access-date=October 4, 2015}}</ref> to August 17, 2015.<ref>{{cite AV media| url=http://www.news-journalonline.com/article/20150817/NEWS/150819635/101040 |title='The Walking Aggie' completes cross-country walk in Daytona |access-date=October 4, 2015}}</ref> Beginning at Scripps Park in La Jolla, California and ending at Daytona Beach, Florida, Ball, age 58, walked 2,686 miles, crossing 8 states in 170 days. His unassisted, uninterrupted walk raised over $27,000 to help establish an Endowed Aggie Ring Scholarship at his alma mater, [[Texas A&M University]].<ref>{{cite AV media| url=http://www.khou.com/story/news/local/2015/06/08/the-walking-aggie-passes-through-houston-area/28706593 | title='The Walking Aggie' passes through Houston area |access-date=October 4, 2015}}</ref>
==Anthony Roddy== Anthony "Silverback" Roddy is a retired USDA Forest Service worker who, at age 56, walked from Wells Beach, Maine, to Imperial Beach, California, between April 19 and December 15, 2015. A US Army veteran of the war in Iraq, he crossed 13 states in 244 days, walking approximately 3,073 miles. His Walkabout-America 2015 was the culmination of a life-long dream, but moreover was an advocacy campaign to help grant wishes to children with life-threatening medical conditions. He raised more than $5,000 for the Make-a-Wish Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kob.com/article/stories/s4001369.shtml#.VprO7VIsLQc |title=Man walks across country to raise money for Make-a-Wish |work=KOB4 Eyewitness News|date=December 24, 2015 |access-date=January 16, 2016}}</ref>
==Jeffrey Grabosky== From January 20 to May 20, 2011, Jeff Grabosky ran solo and unsupported for over 3,700 miles from Oceanside, California to Smith Point, New York. He took prayer intentions from people all around the world and prayed a decade of the rosary for each of the approximate 3,500 intentions he received. His book, ''Running With God Across America'' was published in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/catholic-man-finishes-run-across-america-with-deepened-faith/ |title=Catholic Man Finished Run Across America With Deepened Faith | access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref>
==Bjorn Suneson== In 2016, Bjorn Suneson, a [[Stockholm]] native, finished his fifth run across the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2151&artikel=6480359 |title=Swedish Radio article on Bjorn Suneson | access-date=September 23, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Suneson|first1=Bjorn|title=I made it again – for the fifth time!|url=http://www.suneson.se/kommentarer.php?id=2692|website=Bjorn Suneson - Keep on running|access-date=January 31, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Barrett|first1=Malachi|title=Swedish man passes through Michigan on fifth run across United States|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/muskegon/index.ssf/2016/06/swedish_man_passes_through_mic.html|website=MLive.com|access-date=January 31, 2017}}</ref>
==Mike Maczuzak== Mike Maczuzak, president of SmartShape Design, walked solo and unsupported from Coney Island to Santa Monica Pier, covering more than 3,600 miles in 125 days, and traveling through 15 states, March to July 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://smartshape.design/about/news/smartshapes-mike-maczuzak-completes-walk-across-usa |work=SmartShape Design Media Room |title=SmartShape Design President Completes Walk Across America |author=SmartShape Design |date=August 8, 2016}}</ref>
==Jason P. Lester== Run Across America — Ran 3,550 miles in 72 days averaging 50 miles a day across the United States(4th Fastest athlete to run from San Francisco to New York (July 2013). The run raised money for the Waves for Water organization’s Hurricane Relief Initiative<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://brandchannel.com/2012/05/02/nikes-forrest-gump-ironman-jason-lester-crosses-america-for-nike/|title=Nike's Forrest Gump: Ironman Jason Lester Crosses America for Nike|date=May 2, 2012|website=brandchannel:|access-date=May 17, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wavesforwater.org/fundraiser/run-to-rebuild|title=R[U]N To Rebuild|work=Waves For Water|access-date=May 17, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==Ted G. Stone== [[Ted G. Stone]] was a [[Southern Baptist]] evangelist and recovering amphetamine addict who walked across the United States three times and was on his fourth trip when he died. He made the walks to raise awareness for his ministry to addicts and would drive up to 150 miles off of his walking route to speak to groups. His first trip, in 1996, was 3,650 miles from the Capitol steps in [[Washington, D.C.]], south to [[Jacksonville, Florida]] and west to [[Los Angeles]]. His second trip, in 1998, was a 3,550-mile walk from [[San Francisco]] to [[Virginia Beach, VA]]. His third trip was in 2000 and he walked 1,700 miles from [[Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas]] in [[Mexico]] to the [[Ambassador Bridge]] in [[Detroit]] leading into [[Canada]]. He died on his fourth trip in 2006 in [[Nashville, TN]]. He was walking from [[Chicago]] to [[Pensacola, FL]] which would have covered 1,100 miles.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Ted Stone, 72; Preached During U.S. Walking Tours|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jul/19/local/me-passings19.4|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|location=Los Angeles, California|date=July 19, 2006|access-date=May 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Ted Stone; drug addict became preacher|url=http://archive.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2006/07/20/ted_stone_drug_addict_became_preacher/|newspaper=The Boston Globe|location=Boston, Massacheusetts|date=July 20, 2006|access-date=May 15, 2017}}</ref>
== Benjamin T. Lee == Benjamin Lee, an Australian, walked from San Francisco to Delaware Bay between May 18 and November 30, 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/he-needed-to-do-this-inside-the-obsessive-and-uplifting-world-of-those-who-walk-across-america|title='He needed to do this': Inside the obsessive world of those who walk across America|date=December 21, 2013|work=National Post|access-date=November 20, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fox42kptm.com/archive/aussie-walks-across-america-for-charity|title=Aussie Walks Across America for Charity|last=Group|first=Sinclair Broadcast|work=KPTM|access-date=November 20, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> Lee began his walk with a partner but shortly after a month, his partner quit. He continued his walk solo and unsupported. He raised money for the charity Oxfam.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oxfam.org.au/2013/08/walking-across-america/|title=Walking Across America {{!}} Oxfam Australia|website=Oxfam Australia|language=en-US|access-date=November 20, 2017}}</ref>
== John Ball == John Ball, a graduate from Texas A&M University, walked across the country from March to August 2015. His goal was to raise $25,000 for Aggie Ring scholarships. Ball completed his journey in 170 days, and recorded his journey on a website called The Walking Aggie.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-journalonline.com/news/20150817/the-walking-aggie-completes-cross-country-walk-in-daytona|title='The Walking Aggie' completes cross-country walk in Daytona|first=Richard Conn|last=richard.conn@news-jrnl.com|website=news-journalonline.com|access-date=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
== Yi-joo Kwon == In 2010, Yijoo Kwon of Palisades Park, N.J., ran 95 days from Los Angeles to New York City to raise awareness of diabetes - The New York Times <ref>{{cite web|url=https://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/25/after-3100-miles-a-word-on-diabetes-awareness|title=After 3,100 Miles, a Word on Diabetes Awareness|first=Kirk Semple|last=semplek@nytimes.com|website=nytimes.com|access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref> Yi-joo Kwon, 64, a Korean immigrant and retired businessman runs 3,100-mile coast-to-coast to raise awareness about diabetes - NY Daily News <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/beating-diabetes-flushing-yi-joo-kwon-runs-3-100-miles-raise-awareness-article-1.185719 |title=After beating diabetes, Flushing's Yi-joo Kwon runs 3,100 miles to raise awareness|first=Paul Shin|last=pshin@nydailynews.com|website=nydailynews.com|access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
== Stephan Foust == Between January 28, 1979 and September 6, 1980, Stephan Foust walked 3506 miles across the United States. While en-route, Foust, of Elkhart, Indiana did a weekly remote call-in radio show for WSBT-AM in South Bend, Indiana. The 30-year-old Foust began his journey on the Atlantic Ocean beach at Nags Head, North Carolina, then passed through the states of North Carolina, Tennessee, Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Colorado, Utah, Nevada, and California, before ending his walk on the Pacific Ocean beach of Point Reyes National Seashore. <ref>Hiker Hopes to Uncover The Spirit of Americans by Doug Gardner, The Virginian-Pilot, January 30, 1979</ref><ref>Cross Country Walk Just Research by Mark Kreuzwieser, The Appalachian, March 27, 1979,</ref><ref>Winter Rockies Cool Walk 'n Talk Tour by Milan Simonich, The Pueblo Chieftain, November 5, 1979</ref><ref>Trans-continental Walker Arrives Here by Jon Berry, The Point Reyes Light, September 11, 1980</ref>
== The United Souls of Awareness == The United Souls of Awareness, a creative production team from Los Angeles embarked on a 1 year long walk from Venice Beach California to Manhattan New York from April 1st 2006 to April 1st 2007 . The core members, Kevin Smith II, Kam Talbert, Jordon Cooper, Jonathan White, with many other walkers joining along did this over 4,000 mile walk to encourage self expression, inspire themselves and others and they treked town to town, sharing ideas and information. Then finally ending the walk at a Full Moon Drum circle in New York City at Visionary Artist Alex and Allison Grey New York City Art Gallery COSM. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sharonherald.com/news/local_news/a-trek-of-peace-many-colors-creative-quartet-traveling-from/article_eddb8722-2d13-5275-b482-59803c564d68.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.republicanherald.com/news/tamaqua-man-s-7-acrylic-paintings-help-tell-story-about-walk-across-u-s-1.2025511</ref>
== Shane Moore == Shane Moore did a solo walk from Jacksonville Beach, FL to Ocean Beach, CA in order to raise awareness and money for homeless veterans. He began his walk on Oct, 10, 2017 and officially completed his journey on May 12, 2018. During his journey, he did several TV, newspaper and radio interviews. In total, he walked between 2600 and 2700 miles. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/Navy-Vet-Finishes-Walk-Across-Country-for-Homeless-Vet-Awareness-482465891.html</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hikeforvets.com</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsherald.com/news/20171101/vets-cross-paths-while-hiking-cross-country</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wjhg.com/wecp/content/news/454197923.html</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Biography|United States|Lists}} * [[Transcontinental walk]] * [[List of people who have run across Australia]] * [[List of people who have walked across Australia]] * [[Twenty-first-century fundraising walks in Tasmania]] {{Clear}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * {{Cite book|title=Granny D: Walking Across America in My Ninetieth Year|author=Doris Haddock and Dennis Burke|publisher=Villard Books|year=2001|isbn=978-0-375-50539-3}} * {{Cite book|title=Bold Spirit: Helga Estby's Forgotten Walk Across Victorian America|author=Linda Hunt|publisher=[[University of Idaho Press]]|year=2003|isbn=978-0-89301-262-5}} * {{Cite book|title=Take Steps With A Purpose: A Walk Across America for Cancer Research|author=Eric M. Latham|publisher=Walk About America|year=2006|isbn=1-4243-0760-0}} * {{Cite book|title=Putting a Face on AMERICA|author=Lyn Hanush|publisher=Winepress Publishing|year=2007|isbn=978-1-57921-882-9}} * {{Cite book|title=Walking through the Wall|author=Kevin James Shay|publisher=Lulu Press|year=2012|isbn=978-1-105-60881-0}} * {{Cite book|last=Summerlin|first=Jamie|title=Freedom Run|year=2013|publisher=Fitness Info Tech,West Virginia University|isbn=978-1935412502|pages=264|url=https://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Run-100-Day-452-Mile-Veterans/dp/1935412507/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1393287369&sr=8-1&keywords=freedom+run}} * [http://www.oregonlive.com/today/index.ssf/2013/12/walking_across_america_the_peo.html "Walking across America: The people who do it, at a glance"]. ''The Oregonian''.

{{pp-pc1}} This is a '''list of youngest birth mothers''' between 5 and 10 years of age. ==Age 5== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:10%;"|Date ! style="width:13%;"|Mother ! style="width:9%;"|Age of mother ! class=unsortable style="width:11%;"|Father ! style="width:5%;"|Country ! class=unsortable style="width:32%;"|Description |- | {{Hs|1939-05-14}} May 14, 1939 | [[Lina Medina]] | {{Ntsh|5.07.17}} 5 years,
7 months | Unknown | {{Hs|Peru}} {{flagcountry|Peru|1825}} | [[Lina Medina]], from the [[Ticrapo District]] of Peru, gave birth by [[cesarean section]] in [[Lima]] at age {{frac|5|1|2}}. The infant was a {{convert|2.64|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, {{convert|47.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} boy named Gerardo. Medina's parents, who assumed their daughter had a [[tumor]], took her to a hospital in late March, where she was then found to be 7 months pregnant. By interrogating her parents, the doctors understood that Medina had entered into [[precocious puberty]] (when hormone glands are activated earlier than normal) very early after her birth.{{cite journal|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,893791,00.html|journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|title=Little Mother|date=16 December 1957|accessdate=16 November 2011}}{{cite web|work=Los archivos de la Tierra|url=http://losarchivosdelatierra.com/ciencia/2009/6/4/el-increible-caso-de-lina-medina-madre-a-los-5-aos.html|title=El increíble caso de Lina Medina: Madre a los 5 años|trans-title=The incredible case of Lina Medina: Mother at age 5|date=4 June 2009|accessdate=8 July 2012|language=es|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719065134/http://www.losarchivosdelatierra.com/ciencia/2009/6/4/el-increible-caso-de-lina-medina-madre-a-los-5-aos.html|archivedate=19 July 2011|df=}}{{cite web|publisher=Yahoo Voices|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/the-story-lina-medina-worlds-youngest-mother-447205.html|title=The Story of Lina Medina, the World's Youngest Mother|first=Rachel|last=Bogart|date=20 June 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728221959/http://voices.yahoo.com/the-story-lina-medina-worlds-youngest-mother-447205.html|archivedate=28 July 2014|df=}}{{cite web|publisher=[[Snopes.com]]|url=http://www.snopes.com/pregnant/medina.asp|date =July 21, 2004|title=Youngest Mother|accessdate=16 January 2009|editor1-first=Barbara|editor1-last=Mikkelson|editor2-first=David P. |editor2-last=Mikkelson}}{{cite news|title=Six decades later, world's youngest mother awaits aid|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1020827/asp/foreign/story_1140311.asp |newspaper=[[The Telegraph (Kolkata)|The Telegraph: Calcutta]]|date=27 August 2002|accessdate=30 June 2011}} Although Medina's father was arrested on suspicion of [[child sexual abuse|sexual abuse]], he was later released due to lack of evidence, and the baby's biological father was never identified. |} ==Age 6== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:10%;"|Date ! style="width:13%;"|Mother ! style="width:9%;"|Age of mother ! class=unsortable style="width:15%;"|Father ! style="width:11%;"|Country ! class=unsortable style="width:42%;"|Description |- | {{Hs|1932-06-07}} June 7, 1932 | {{sort|H.|H.}} | {{Ntsh|6.07.27}} 6 years,
7 months | Unknown | {{Hs|India}} {{flagicon|British Raj}} [[British Raj|British India]]
(now {{flagcountry|India}}) | The 6-year-old known only as "H." gave birth by cesarean section to a girl weighing {{convert|4.19|lb|kg|abbr=on}} at Victoria Zanana Hospital in [[Delhi, India]]. She was initially admitted for what was thought to be an abdominal tumor, as she complained of localized pain in her lower abdomen. Her father said she was 7, but civic records gave her birth date as October 11, 1925, making her 6 years and 7 months old at the time of labor. She had never [[Menstruation|menstruated]] and her breasts were still far from being fully developed, yet she was able to breastfeed her child for 9 months.{{cite journal |last1=Keane |first1=Hilda L. |last2= |first2= |year=1933 |title=A Case of Maternity at Seven Years of Age |journal=[[British Medical Journal]] |volume=2 |issue=3794 |pages=567–569 |publisher= |doi=10.1136/bmj.2.3794.567 |url=http://www.bmj.com/content/2/3794/567 |accessdate=9 December 2011}} |- | {{Hs|1934-08-19}} August 19, 1934 | {{sortname|Yelizaveta "Liza"|Pantueva|nolink=1}}
({{lang|ru|Елизавета "Лиза" Пантуева}}) | {{Ntsh|6.0.5}} 6 years | Her 70-year-old maternal grandfather | {{Hs|Soviet Union}} {{flagcountry|Soviet Union}}
(now {{flagcountry|Ukraine}}) | Yelizaveta "Liza" Pantueva was 5 years old when her 70-year-old maternal grandfather raped and impregnated her. She had her 6th birthday several days before giving birth. Pantueva's parents did not want the obstetricians to perform a cesarean section, as it was considered dangerous at the time. She gave birth in [[Kharkiv]], with the aid of [[Forceps in childbirth|forceps]] and [[Retractor (medical)|retractors]]. The {{convert|3|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, {{convert|52|cm|in|abbr=on}} infant girl died during labor due to an early [[placenta]]l tear; she had been born at full term and apparently of good constitution and, according to doctors, would have survived if she had been extracted more quickly, revived, and oxygenated. After the incident, the family emigrated to [[Vladivostok]], taking the girl's grandfather with them.{{cite web|url=http://fakty.ua/65765-samaya-molodaya-mama-v-istorii-chelovechestva-shestiletnyaya-liza-iz-harkova-zaberemenela-ot-sobstvennogo-deda-moryaka |script-title=ru:Самая молодая мама в истории человечества 6-летняя Лиза из Харькова, забеременела... от собственного деда-моряка|trans-title=The youngest mother in history is 6-year-old Lisa from Kharkov, who's pregnant ... by her grandfather, a sailor |author=Tkachuk, Tapac |date=2 April 2004 |work=[[Fakty i Kommentarii]]|accessdate=16 November 2011|language=ru}} |} ==Age 8== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:10%;"|Date ! style="width:13%;"|Mother ! style="width:9%;"|Age of mother ! class=unsortable style="width:15%;"|Father ! style="width:11%;"|Country ! class=unsortable style="width:42%;"|Description |- | {{Hs|1759-12-05}} December 5, 1759 | {{sortname|Anna|Mummenthaler|nolink=1}} | {{Ntsh|8.09}}8 years,
9 months | A relative of her parents | {{Hs|Switzerland}} {{flagcountry|Old Swiss Confederacy}}
(now {{flagcountry|Switzerland}}) | Anna Mummenthaler of [[Lauperswil|Lauperswil, Canton of Bern]] gave birth to a stillborn girl when she was 8 years old.{{cite journal |last1=Schmidt |first1= |last2= |first2= |year=1760 |title= Lettre écrite à Monsr. J. J. d'Annoni|trans-title=Letter written to Mr. J. J. d'Annoi |journal= Acta helvetica |volume=4 |issue= |pages=167–168 |publisher= |doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ghQUAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA167#v=onepage |accessdate=11 December 2011|language=fr}} |- | {{Hs|1884-12-00}} December 1884 | {{sort|Mum-Zi|Mum-Zi}} | {{Ntsh|8.04}}8 years,
4 months | Chief Akkiri | [[File:Flag_of_the_Niger_Coast_Protectorate.svg|23px]] [[Niger Coast Protectorate|Niger Coast]]
(now {{Hs|Nigeria}} {{flagcountry|Nigeria}}) | Mum-Zi was a member of Chief Akkiri's [[harem]] on the island of [[Calabar]]. Her daughter also gave birth extremely early, making Mum-Zi a grandmother at age 17.{{cite web | url = http://www.nealirc.org/Gerontology/FamilyRecord.html | title = Family Records | publisher = Nealirc.org | date = | accessdate =13 August 2010}}{{Self-published source|date=November 2012}}{{cite book|first=Archibald|last=Lyall|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6mAVAAAAIAAJ|title=The Future of Taboo in These Islands|year=1936|page=114|publisher=K. Paul, Trench, Trubner|asin=B0006DAYAW}} |- | {{Hs|1893-08-00}} August 1893 | {{sort|Zi|Zi}} | {{Ntsh|8.08}}8 years,
8 months | A relative or familiar of Chief Akkiri | [[File:Flag_of_the_Niger_Coast_Protectorate.svg|23px]] [[Niger Coast Protectorate|Niger Coast]]
(now {{Hs|Nigeria}} {{flagcountry|Nigeria}}) | Zi, Mum-Zi's daughter, became a mother at the age of 8 years 8 months. |- | {{Hs|1933-08-00}} August 1933 | {{sort|ZZ|Unidentified}} | {{Ntsh|8}} 8 years | Her husbandGirls in India could customarily be married after reaching puberty. | {{Hs|India}} {{flagicon|British Raj}} [[British Raj|British India]]
(now {{flagcountry|India}}) | An unidentified 8-year-old girl in [[Kashmir]] reportedly died in labor along with her child. The girl's mother, a destitute widow, said she had been forced to accept an offer of marriage for her daughter.{{cite journal |last1=Vaughn |first1=Kathleen |last2= |first2= |year=1933 |title= Pregnancy in Childhood |journal=British Medical Journal|volume=2 |issue=3798 |page=759 |publisher= |doi= 10.1136/bmj.2.3798.759-a|url=http://ukpmc.ac.uk/articles/PMC2369490/?page=1 |accessdate=12 December 2012|pmc=2369490}} |- | {{Hs|1936-09-13}} September 13, 1936 | {{sortname|Griseldina|Acuña|nolink=1}} | {{Ntsh|8.02.05}} 8 years,
2 months | A family friend | {{Hs|Colombia}} {{flagcountry|Colombia}} | Griseldina Acuña of [[San Zenón|San Zenón, Magdalena Department]], gave birth to a boy weighing {{convert|5|lb|kg|abbr=on}}. She was reported to have begun menstruating at age 3.{{cite journal |last1=Restrepo |first1=Alonso|last2=Perez R.|first2=Hernal|last3=Uribe Piedrahita|first3=Cesar|last4=Urueta F.|first4=Carlos Adolfo|last5=Uribe Jaramillo|first5=Eugenio|last6=Grau|first6=Luis Carlos|date=1 June 1937 |title= Maternidad precoz|trans-title=Precocious maternity |journal=Boletín Clínico [Clinical Bulletin] |volume=3 |number=9 |pages=479–499 |publisher= |doi= |url=http://tesis.udea.edu.co/dspace/handle/10495/1502 |accessdate=28 December 2011|language=es}} |- | {{Hs|1957-12-02}} December 2, 1957 | {{sortname|Hilda|Trujillo|nolink=1}} | {{Ntsh|8.07.28}} 8 years,
7 months | Her 22-year-old cousin | {{Hs|Peru}} {{flagcountry|Peru}} | Hilda Trujillo gave birth to a girl named María del Rosario, who was over {{convert|6|lb|abbr=on}}, at a hospital in Lima. Contrary to what was reported in ''[[Time Magazine|Time]]'' on December 16, 1957 and many other sources, she was not 9 years old, but rather one year younger.{{cite news|url=http://wvw.nacion.com/ln_ee/2008/enero/05/pais1370364.html|newspaper=[[La Nación]]| title=8 years 7 months 28 days mother|date=5 January 1958|accessdate=13 May 2012}} The rapist was a 22-year-old cousin who had been staying in her family's one-room residence. He was later arrested. |- | {{Hs|1993-01-12}} January 12, 1993 | {{sortname|Zulma|Guadalupe Morales|nolink=1}} | {{Ntsh|8}}8 years | Her uncle | {{Hs|Mexico}} {{flagcountry|Mexico}} | Zulma Guadalupe Morales, age 8. Her uncle raped her.{{cite news|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1993/gennaio/15/partorisce_otto_anni_bambina_violentata_co_0_930115975.shtml|title= Bambina, violentata dallo zio, partorisce a 8 anni|trans-title=Girl, raped by her uncle, gives birth at 8-year |date=15 January 1993|newspaper=[[Corriere della Sera]] |accessdate=12 May 2012|language=it}} She gave birth by cesarean section to a boy weighing {{convert|7.04|lb|kg|abbr=on}} at a hospital in [[Guadalajara, Jalisco]].{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/270053/8-YEAR-OLD-GIVES-BIRTH-IN-MEXICO.html |title= 8-Year-Old Gives Birth in Mexico |date=15 January 1993 |newspaper=[[Deseret News]] |accessdate=16 November 2011}} |- | {{Hs|2000-04-00}} April 2000 | {{sort|Anna|Anna "Anya"}}

7 months | Her 13-year-old neighbor | {{Hs|Russia}} {{flagcountry|Russia}} | Anya reached puberty at 7. A 13-year-old neighbor raped her. 11 months | S.D., the uncle of her grandmother's tenant | {{Hs|Senegal}} {{flagcountry|Senegal}} | An orphan girl "Zeina" was from neighborhood in [[Dakar, Senegal]], and brought up by her grandmother. The grandmother had a tenant. The tenant's uncle, nearly 60 years old, raped the orphan girl. Noting the absence of her menstruations and her weight gain, her grandmother and her aunt became aware of her pregnancy in June, when she was 5 months pregnant. Zeina gave birth by cesarean section at the Grand Yoff Hospital,{{cite news|url=http://www.lemessagersn.info/Histoire-rocambolesque-Mere-a-10-ans-des-suites-d-un-viol_a6270.html |title=Mère à 10 ans, des suites d'un viol |date=2010-10-05 |newspaper=[[Le Messager]] |language=fr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101217052709/http://lemessagersn.info/Histoire-rocambolesque-Mere-a-10-ans-des-suites-d-un-viol_a6270.html |archivedate=December 17, 2010 }} to a daughter she rejected.{{cite web|url=http://senxibaar.blogspot.fr/2010/12/mere-lage-de-10-ans-zeina-victime-dun.html|title=Mère sous 10 ans : Zeina victime d'un viol suivi de grossesse|author=Rokia |date=2010-12-10|language=fr}}{{self-published inline|date=November 2012}} |- | {{Hs|2013-01-13}} January 27, 2013 | {{sort|ZZ|Dafne}} | {{Ntsh|9}}9 years | Unidentified | {{Hs|Mexico}} {{flag|Mexico}} | Dr. Enrique Rabago, director of the Zoquipan Hospital, reported the girl and baby daughter were healthy and had returned home after receiving a [[Caesarean section]]. Dafne is one of 11 children and lives in [[Ixtlahuacan de los Membrillos]]. The 17-year-old father and Dafne were dating. A search for the baby's 17-year-old father, who may be criminally charged for having a sexual relationship with the young girl, was underway.{{cite web|title=Girl, 9, Gives Birth in Mexico|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/health/2013/02/06/girl-9-gives-birth-in-mexico/|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=6 February 2013}} She was reportedly sterilized shortly after the birth.{{cite news|last=Tate|first=Amethyst|title=Dafne, Pregnant 9-Year-Old in Mexico, Sterilized After Giving Birth|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/dafne-pregnant-9-year-old-mexico-sterilized-after-giving-birth-1070374|accessdate=8 February 2013|newspaper=International Business Times|date=7 February 2013}} However, questions have emerged about her true age, as she appeared to be around 15. {{flagcountry|Haiti|size=15px}}) | A 10-year-old Haitian girl of Lantana, [[Florida]], became pregnant after a 33-year-old man raped her when she was 9. Her father learned of her pregnancy only when he took her to the clinic when she suffered [[Contraction (childbirth)|labor contractions]] on March 18, 2009. The same day, she gave birth naturally to a full-term boy. Reluctantly, she exposed Datilus to investigators who interviewed her through a [[Haitian Creole]] interpreter (she spoke only little English, having arrived illegally in the U.S. only 30 months before). She confided that she had been afraid that she and her father would be deported to Haiti – a threat the rapist had used against her. Datilus was sentenced to life imprisonment for raping a minor under 12 years, to which 5 years for impregnating her was added.{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2011-03-23/news/fl-pregnant-child-sentence-20110323_1_impregnating-lantana-man-maximum-sentence|title=Lantana man gets life in prison for impregnating girl, 9|date=2011-03-23|work=SunSentinel|last=Roustan|first=Wayne K.}} |- | {{Hs|2009-04-00}} April 2009 | {{sort|ZZ|Unidentified}} | {{Ntsh|10.09}} 10 years,

She gave birth one month before term by cesarean section to a {{convert|2.420|kg|lb|abbr=on}}, {{convert|45|cm|in|abbr=on}} girl, who was named Tatiana and placed in an [[Incubator (neonatal)|incubator]] and on a drip-feed.{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1472559-una-nina-de-10-anos-fue-madre-en-corrientes|title=Una niña de 10 años violada por un primo lejano de 15 años fue madre en Corrientes|trans-title=Girl of 10 years raped by distant cousin, age 15, became mother in Corrientes|work=lanacion [thenation]|date=2012-05-12|language=es}} |- | {{Hs|2015-13-08}} August 13, 2015 | {{sort|ZZ|Mainumby}} | {{Ntsh|10}}10 years | Gilberto Benítez Zárate, her 42-year-old stepfather | {{Hs|Paraguay}} {{flag|Paraguay}} | Brought to an [[Asunción]] hospital by her mother, who believed that she was developing a [[tumor]], where doctors discovered that she was five months pregnant and alerted authorities. The doctors told the mother that her daughter's life was at risk and she requested an abortion to the Paraguayan government, which denied it. The case in turn generated debate nationally and abroad regarding Paraguay's strict anti-abortion laws.{{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/internacional/2015/05/05/actualidad/1430843506_403313.html|title=Paraguay impide el aborto de una niña violada de 10 años y 34 kilos|first=Carlos E.|last=Cué|date=5 May 2015|publisher=|via=elpais.com}} The stepfather fled, but was arrested in Boquerón, [[Caazapá Department]]. He denied being the father but was identified as such through a DNA test. Mainumby's mother had denounced Benítez for sexual abuse of her daughter four times in the previous year, but the authorities never intervened. After the doctors's discovery, she was herself arrested and charged with negligence and sexual abuse of a child, and sentenced to two months in prison after being found guilty of the former.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.com.py/nacionales/adn-comprueba-paternidad-de-padrastro-1415203.html|title=ADN comprobó la paternidad de denunciado — Nacionales — ABC Color|first=ABC|last=Color|website=abc.com.py}} |} ==See also== {{col-begin}}{{col-break|width=40%}} *[[Age of consent]] *[[Child sexual abuse]] *[[Child sexuality]] *[[List of child brides]] *[[List of oldest fathers|List of oldest birth fathers]] *[[List of oldest mothers|List of oldest birth mothers]] *[[List of people with the most children]] {{col-break|width=40%}} *[[List of multiple births]] *[[List of youngest birth fathers]] *[[Lolita (term)]] *[[Mother]] *[[Precocious puberty]] *[[Pregnancy]] *[[Teenage pregnancy]] {{col-end}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Youngest Birth Mothers}} [[Category:Child sexual abuse]] [[Category:Lists of women]] [[Category:Lists of the youngest people|Birth mothers]] [[Category:Motherhood]] [[Category:Precocious puberty and pregnancy]] [[Category:Preteen pregnancy]] [[Category:Adolescent sexuality]] [[Category:Biological records]]
