revision.text:
{{Infobox interventions | Name = Natural childbirth | Image = | Caption = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICD9_mult = | MeshID = D009321 | OPS301 = | OtherCodes = | }} '''Natural childbirth''' is [[childbirth]] without routine medical interventions, particularly [[anesthesia]]. Natural childbirth arose in opposition to the techno-medical model of childbirth that has recently gained popularity in industrialized societies. Natural childbirth attempts to minimize medical intervention, particularly the use of anesthetic medications and surgical interventions such as [[episiotomies]], forceps and [[ventouse]] deliveries and [[caesarean section]]s. Natural childbirth may occur during a physician or midwife attended [[hospital birth]], a midwife attended homebirth, or an unassisted birth. The term "natural childbirth" was coined by obstetrician [[Grantly Dick-Read]] upon publication of his book ''Natural Childbirth'' in the 1930s, which was followed by the 1942 ''Childbirth Without Fear''.
==History== Historically, most women gave birth at home without emergency medical care available. The "natural" rate of maternal mortality—meaning without surgical or pharmaceutical intervention—has been estimated at 1,500 per 100,000 births. In the United States circa 1900, before the introduction and improvement of modern medical technologies, there were about 700 maternal deaths per 100,000 births (.7%).<ref name="vanlerberghe">Van Lerberghe W, De Brouwere V. ''Of blind alleys and things that have worked: history’s lessons on reducing maternal mortality.'' In: De Brouwere V, Van Lerberghe W, eds. ''Safe motherhood strategies: a review of the evidence''. Antwerp, ITG Press, 2001 (Studies in Health Services Organisation and Policy, 17:7–33). "Where nothing effective is done to avert maternal death, “natural” mortality is probably of the order of magnitude of 1,500/100,000...In the USA of 1900, for example, there were about 700 maternal deaths for 100,000 births"</ref>
At the onset of the [[Industrial Revolution]], giving birth at home became more difficult due to congested living spaces and dirty living conditions. This drove urban and lower class women to newly available hospitals, while wealthy and middle-class women continued to labor at home.<ref name=Cassidy>{{cite book|last = Cassidy|first = Tina|title = Birth|publisher= Atlantic Monthly Press|location= New York|year= 2006|pages = 54–55 |isbn = 0-87113-938-3}}</ref> In the early 1900s there was an increasing availability of hospitals, and more women began going into the hospital for labor and delivery. In the United States, the middle classes were especially receptive to the medicalization of childbirth, which promised a safer and less painful labor.<ref name=Thompson>{{cite journal |year = 2005 |title = Consumer Risk Perceptions in a Community of Reflexive Doubt |journal = Journal of Consumer Research|volume = 32|pages = 235–248 |doi = 10.1086/432233 |author = Thompson, Craig J. |authormask = Thompson, C.J. |issue = 2}}</ref> The ability to birth without pain was part of the early feminist movement.{{ref|Cassidy}} The use of childbirth drugs began in 1847 when Scottish obstetrician [[James Young Simpson]] introduced chloroform as an anesthetic during labor, but only the most rich and powerful women (such as [[Queen Victoria]]) had access. In the late 1800s, feminists in the United States and United Kingdom began to demand drugs for pain relief during childbirth.<ref name="Downe2008">{{cite book|author=Susan Downe|title=Normal Childbirth: Evidence and Debate|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G1F0tPKzgSAC&pg=PA37|date=30 May 2008|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=0-7020-3792-3|pages=37–}}</ref>
The term "natural childbirth" was coined by obstetrician [[Grantly Dick-Read]] upon publication of his book ''Natural Childbirth'' in the 1930s. In 1942 [[Grantly Dick-Read]] published ''Revelation of Childbirth'' (which was later retitled ''Childbirth without Fear''), advocating natural childbirth, which became an international bestseller. The [[Lamaze method]] of natural childbirth gained popularity in the United States after Marjorie Karmel wrote about her experiences in her 1959 book ''Thank You, Dr. Lamaze'', and with the formation of the American Society for Psychoprophylaxis in Obstetrics (currently [[Lamaze International]]) by Marjorie Karmel and [[Elisabeth Bing]]. Later, physicians [[Michel Odent]] and [[Frederick Leboyer]] and midwives such as [[Ina May Gaskin]] promoted [[birthing center]]s, [[water birth]], and [[homebirth]] as alternatives to the hospital model. The [[Bradley method of natural childbirth]] (also known as "husband-coached childbirth"), a method of natural childbirth developed in 1947 by Robert A. Bradley, M.D., was popularized by his book ''Husband-Coached Childbirth'', first published in 1965.
==Psychological aspects== Many women consider natural birth empowering.<ref>''Having a Great Birth in Australia'', [[David Vernon (writer)|David Vernon]], Australian College of Midwives, 2005</ref> Studies show that skin-to-skin contact between a mother and her newborn immediately after birth is beneficial for both mother and baby. A review done by the [[World Health Organization]] found that skin-to-skin contact between mothers and babies after birth reduces crying, improves mother-infant interaction, and helps mothers to breastfeed successfully. They recommend that [[neonates]] be allowed to bond with the mother during their first two hours after birth, the period that they tend to be more alert than in the following hours of early life.<ref>http://apps.who.int/rhl/newborn/gpcom/en/index.html</ref>
==Alternatives to intervention== Instead of medical interventions, a variety of non-invasive methods are employed during natural childbirth to ease the mother's pain. Many of these techniques stress the importance of "a mind-body connection," which the techno-medical model of birth does not. These techniques include [[hydrotherapy]], [[massage]], [[Relaxation technique|relaxation]] therapy, [[hypnosis]], [[breath]]ing exercises, acupressure for labor, [[transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation]] (TENS), [[Speech production|vocalization]], [[Mental image|visualization]], [[mindfulness (psychology)|mindfulness]] and [[water birth]]. Other approaches include movement, walking, and different positions (for example, using a [[birthing ball]]), hot and cold therapy (for example, using hot compresses and/or cold packs), and receiving one-on-one labor support like that provided by a [[midwife]] or [[doula]]. However, natural childbirth proponents maintain that pain is a natural and necessary part of the labor process, and should not automatically be regarded as entirely negative. In contrast to the pain of injury and disease, they believe that the pain of childbirth is a sign that the female body is functioning as it is meant to.
Birth positions favored in natural childbirth—including [[Squatting position|squatting]], hands and knees, or suspension in water—contrast with the [[lithotomy position]] (woman in hospital bed on her back with legs in stirrups), which has consistently been shown to slow and complicate labor.<ref>{{cite book|last=Davis-Floyd|first=Robbie|title=Birth as an American Rite of Passage|year=2004|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=0-520-22932-0}}</ref>
Methods to reduce tearing during natural childbirth (instead of an [[episiotomy]]) include managing the [[perineum]] with counter-pressure,<ref name=WHO>{{cite web |author = World Health Organization|year =1997 |title = Care in normal birth: A practical guide|url = http://www.who.int/reproductive-health/publications/MSM_96_24/MSM_96_24_chapter4.en.html}}</ref> hot compresses, and pushing the baby out slowly.
==Preparation== Some women take birth education classes such as [[Lamaze]] or the [[Bradley method of natural childbirth|Bradley Method]] to prepare for a natural childbirth. Several books are also available with information to help women prepare. A midwife or [[doula]] may include preparation for a natural birth as part of the prenatal care services. However, a study published in 2009 suggests that preparation alone is not enough to ensure an intervention-free outcome.<ref>http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/122394587/HTMLSTART?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0</ref>
==Prevalence of medical intervention in the U.S.== In the U.S in 2007: 93% of mothers used [[cardiotocography|electronic fetal monitoring]]; 63% used [[epidural]]s; 55% had their [[rupture of membranes|membranes ruptured]]; 53% received [[oxytocin]] to stimulate labor progress; and 52% received [[episiotomy|episiotomies]].<ref name=Gissespie>{{cite web |author=Gissespie, M., Strauss, M |year = 2007 |title = What Women Aren’t Told about Childbirth |url = http://www.alternet.org/story/65608}}</ref>
==Criticisms==
Some studies argue that the push towards 'natural childbirth' in [[Developed countries|Western countries]] is exaggerated, and can harm women.<ref>''Articles'': * {{cite news | last = Glaser | first = Elaine | title = The cult of natural childbirth has gone too far | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/mar/05/natural-childbirth-report-midwife-musketeers-morcambe-bay | work = [[The Guardian]] | Opinion | date = 5 March 2015 | access-date = 2 October 2017}} * {{cite news | last = Freeman | first = Hadley | author-link = Hadley Freeman | title = The obsession with ‘natural’ birth is just another way to judge a woman | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/may/29/obsession-natural-birth-judge-women-pregnant-medical | work = [[The Guardian]] | Comment is free | date = 29 May 2015 | access-date = 2 October 2017}} * {{cite news | last = Phipps | first = Alison | title = The drive for 'natural motherhood' | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/health-27239241 | work = Scrubbing Up | publisher = [[BBC]] | date = 9 May 2014 | access-date = 2 October 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Bradley method of natural childbirth]] * [[Childbirth positions]] * [[Early postnatal hospital discharge]] * [[Home birth]] * [[Hypnotherapy in childbirth]] * ''[[Natural Hospital Birth]]'' * [[Squatting position]]
==Further reading== * Durand, Mark A. (1992). [http://www.thefarm.org/charities/mid.html "The Safety of Home Birth: The Farm Study"]. ''American Journal of Public Health''. * Sakala, C., M. Corry, and H. Goer (2004). [http://www.childbirthconnection.org/article.asp?ck=10271 "Harms of Cesarean Versus Vaginal Birth"]. New York: [[Childbirth Connection]]. Full report available at * Simkin, P. (1992). "Just another day in a woman's life? Nature and consistency of women's long term memories of their first birth experience". ''Birth'' 19:64–81. * Thompson, Craig (2005). [http://gatton.uky.edu/courseweb/99/JCR%202005-09%20Thompson.pdf "Consumer Risk Perceptions in a Community of Reflexive Doubt"]. ''Journal of Consumer Research''.

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = NextGen Jane | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | trading_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | romanized_name = | former_name = | type = | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Biotechnology]] and [[Genomics]] | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = 2014 | founder = | defunct = <!-- {{end date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location = | hq_location_city = [[Oakland, California]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | coordinates = | num_locations = | num_locations_year = <!-- Year of num_locations data (when known) --> | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = Ridhi Tariyal (Co-founder), Stephen Gire, (Co-founder) | products = | brands = | production = | production_year = <!-- Year of production data (when known) --> | services = | revenue = | revenue_year = <!-- Year of revenue data (when known) --> | operating_income = | income_year = <!-- Year of operating_income data (when known) --> | net_income = <!-- or: | profit = --> | net_income_year = <!-- or: | profit_year = --><!-- Year of net_income/profit data (when known) --> | aum = <!-- Only for financial-service companies --> | assets = | assets_year = <!-- Year of assets data (when known) --> | equity = | equity_year = <!-- Year of equity data (when known) --> | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | members = | members_year = <!-- Year of members data (when known) --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (when known) --> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | slogan = <!-- or: | slogans = --> | module = <!-- Used to embed other templates --> | website = {{URL|http://www.nextgenjane.com/}} | footnotes = | intl = <!-- Set positively ("true"/"yes"/etc) if company is international, otherwise omit --> }}
'''NextGen Jane''' is a data driven women’s healthcare company known for inventing a smart [[tampon]] system that offers insight into a woman's reproductive health system.<ref>{{cite news | last =Mark | first =Prigg | title = Prigg The smart tampon that can give you a monthly checkup: Startup hopes to allow women to test menstrual blood at home | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''dailymail.co.uk''| date =1 April 2016 | url =http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3618527/The-smart-tampon-monthly-checkup-Startup-hopes-allow-women-test-menstrual-blood-home.html | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Pagan | first =Kennedy | title =The Tampon of the Future | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''nytimes.com''| date =1 April 2016 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/03/opinion/sunday/the-tampon-of-the-future.html | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =ELIZABETH | first =SEGRAN | title =The Quantified Vagina: This Startup Aims To Track Women’s Health Through Smart Tampons | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''fastcompany.com''| date = | url =https://www.fastcompany.com/3059799/the-quantified-vagina-this-startup-aims-to-track-womens-health-through-smart-tampons | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Silas | first =Alexander | title =NEW PARADIGM FOR WOMEN’S HEALTH | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''studiofathom.com''| date =28 March 2016 | url =http://studiofathom.com/blog/fathom-ngj-new-paradigm-womens-health/ | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref>
==History== In 2013 co-founder Ridhi Tariyal was part of the first class of the Blavatnik Fellowship at [[Harvard University]].<ref>{{cite news | last =SARAH | first =ZHANG | title =Hey Silicon Valley, Let’s Talk About Periods | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''wired.com''| date =4 July 2016 | url =https://www.wired.com/2016/04/hey-silicon-valley-lets-talk-periods/ | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref> The purpose of the fellowship is to place recent MBA graduates in labs across Harvard with the goal to commercialize life science-based enterprises.<ref>{{cite news | last =Shepherd | first =Laughlin | title =Ridhi Tariyal, cofounder, NextGen Jane| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''jwtintelligence.com''| date =27 July 2017 | url =https://www.jwtintelligence.com/2017/07/ridhi-tariyal-cofounder-nextgen-jane/ | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref>
Coming out of the fellowship Tariyal and co-founder Stephen Gire developed intellectual property for a Smart Tampon System to gather genomic information about a woman’s health.<ref>{{cite news | last =Alec | first = O| title =3D printed tampon accessory by NextGen Jane enables self-testing for STDs | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''3ders.org''| date = | url =http://www.3ders.org/articles/20160617-3d-printed-tampon-accessory-by-nextgen-jane-enables-self-testing-for-stds.html | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Charles | first =Moore | title =Harvard-mentored Researchers Developing At-Home Product to Detect Endrometriosis and ‘Silent Infections’ in Women | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''endometriosisnews.com''| date =12 April 2016 | url =https://endometriosisnews.com/2016/04/12/researchers-developing-diagnostic-technology-to-help-women-monitor-their-own-health-and-fertility/ | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref>
NextGen Jane was founded in 2014 with this IP as its core [[patent]] technology and its headquarters are located in [[Oakland, California]], [[United States]].<ref>{{cite news | last =Tanaya | first =Singh | title =Indian American Entrepreneur Co-Develops Smart Tampons to Help Women Detect Cervical Cancer & More | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''thebetterindia.com''| date = | url =https://www.thebetterindia.com/57009/smart-tampons-reproductive-health-indian-american-entrepreneur/ | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref> Initially, the company had nothing to do with tampon. It was about fertility and empowering women to manage their own reproductive health by themselves.<ref>{{cite news | last =Caroline | first =Perry | title =Our blood, ourselves| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''news.harvard.edu''| date =4 April 2016 | url =https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2016/04/our-blood-ourselves/ | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref> Later on, the tampoon aspect was added to help women manage their reproductive healthcare much better.<ref>{{cite news | last =Annamarya | first =Scaccia | title =How Much Will The "Smart" Tampon Cost? The Motivation Behind It Is Too Awesome| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''romper.com''| date =22 February 2017 | url =https://www.romper.com/p/how-much-will-the-smart-tampon-cost-the-motivation-behind-it-is-too-awesome-39876 | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Andrea | first =Frazier | title =How To Get The New Tampon From NextGen Jane, Because It Will Be An Important Health Tool | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''romper.com''| date =17 February 2017| url =https://www.romper.com/p/how-to-get-the-new-tampon-from-nextgen-jane-because-it-will-be-important-health-tool-38873 | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref>
==Products and services== NextGen Jane offers insight into women's reproductive health through its Smart Tampon System - a device that can help track biological changes in a woman’s body and enables them to manage their healthcare more autonomously.<ref>{{cite news | last =Lindsay | first =Gellman | title =Ida Tin’s Battle to Build Clue, a Period-Tracking App | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''newyorker.com''| date =19 March 2017| url =https://www.newyorker.com/business/currency/ida-tins-battle-to-build-clue-a-period-tracking-app | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Abigail | first =Wise | title =Pregnancy Health For The Better | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''romper.com''| date =14 February 2017| url =https://www.romper.com/p/this-new-tampon-could-change-pregnancy-health-for-the-better-22880 | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =KITTY | first =KNOWLES | title =6 ‘Tampons of the Future’ that are bloody great | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''thememo.com''| date =28 June 2017| url =https://www.thememo.com/2017/06/28/smart-tampons-womens-health-tampon-subscriptions-uk-us-sex-on-period/ | accessdate =10 October 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:American companies established in 2014]] [[Category:Companies based in Oakland, California]] [[Category:Health care companies based in California]] [[Category:Women's health]]

revision.comment: Alter: pmc. Add: pmid, doi, issue, volume, pages. Removed parameters. Formatted [[WP:ENDASH|dashes]]. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]]; [[Category:CS1 maint: PMC format]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Press Ganey Associates | logo = | type = | industry = [[Health care]] | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founded = 1985 | founder = | defunct = | hq_location_city = [[South Bend]], [[Indiana]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = | key_people = Patrick T. Ryan ([[CEO]])
Irwin Press and Rod Ganey (cofounders) | products = | owner = | num_employees = 1,000+ | num_employees_year = 2015{{Cite news |url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/news/business/press-ganey-marks-th-anniversary/article_1c306104-3b54-11e5-98c9-5f649bd56919.html |title=Press Ganey marks 30th anniversary |date=2015-08-05 |work=South Bend Tribune |access-date=2018-10-26 |language=en}} | parent = | website = {{url|http://www.pressganey.com/}} }} '''Press Ganey Associates''' is a [[South Bend]], [[Indiana]]-based [[health care]] company known for developing and distributing [[patient satisfaction]] [[survey (human research)|survey]]s. As of January 2017, its Medical Practice Survey was the most widely used [[outpatient]] satisfaction survey in the [[United States]].{{Cite journal |last=Presson |first=Angela P. |last2=Zhang |first2=Chong |last3=Abtahi |first3=Amir M. |last4=Kean |first4=Jacob |last5=Hung |first5=Man |last6=Tyser |first6=Andrew R. |date=January 2017 |title=Psychometric properties of the Press Ganey® Outpatient Medical Practice Survey |journal=Health and Quality of Life Outcomes |language=En |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=32 |doi=10.1186/s12955-017-0610-3 |issn=1477-7525 |pmc=5301343 |pmid=28183312}} ==History== Press Ganey Associates was founded in 1985 by medical anthropologist Irwin Press and sociologist-statistician Rod Ganey, both of whom were then professors at the [[University of Notre Dame]]. Over the next fifteen years, the company's client base, which initially consisted of only a few hospitals, grew steadily in size.{{Cite journal |last=Jr. |first=Richard Bolton Siegrist, |date=2013-11-02 |title=Patient Satisfaction: History, Myths, and Misperceptions |url=https://journalofethics.ama-assn.org/article/patient-satisfaction-history-myths-and-misperceptions/2013-11 |journal=AMA Journal of Ethics |volume=15 |issue=11 |pages=982–987 |access-date=2018-10-25|doi=10.1001/virtualmentor.2013.15.11.mhst1-1311 |pmid=24257092 }} In 1993, [[Mel Hall (politician)|Mel Hall]] began working at Press Ganey, and in 2001, he became its [[CEO]]. He remained the company's CEO until stepping down in 2012 to found the [[Nashville]]-based medical staffing firm SpecialtyCare.{{Cite news |url=https://www.southbendtribune.com/news/politics/former-ceo-mel-hall-announces-bid-to-unseat-jackie-walorski/article_fb22ee6a-addd-11e7-bce5-972748578eda.html |title=Former CEO Mel Hall announces bid to unseat Jackie Walorski |last=writer |first=Jeff Parrott Staff |work=South Bend Tribune |access-date=2018-10-25 |language=en}} The [[Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] previously used Press Ganey's survey to measure patient satisfaction, but in 2012, after the survey was widely criticized, they replaced it with the Hospital Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems (HCAHPS).{{Cite journal |last=Zusman |first=Edie E. |date=August 2012 |title=HCAHPS Replaces Press Ganey Survey as Quality Measure for Patient Hospital Experience |url=https://academic.oup.com/neurosurgery/article/71/2/N21/2595747 |journal=Neurosurgery |language=en |volume=71 |issue=2 |pages=N21–N24 |doi=10.1227/01.neu.0000417536.07871.ed |pmid=22811203 |issn=0148-396X}} As of November 2016, Press Ganey's surveys are in use at more than 10,000 medical institutions.{{Cite journal |last=Etier |first=Brian E. |last2=Orr |first2=Scott P. |last3=Antonetti |first3=Jonathan |last4=Thomas |first4=Scott B. |last5=Theiss |first5=Steven M. |date=November 2016 |title=Factors impacting Press Ganey patient satisfaction scores in orthopedic surgery spine clinic |url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1529943016300353 |journal=The Spine Journal |volume=16 |issue=11 |pages=1285–1289 |doi=10.1016/j.spinee.2016.04.007 |pmid=27084192 |issn=1529-9430}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.pressganey.com/}} {{Med-company-stub}} [[Category:1985 establishments in Indiana]] [[Category:Health care companies established in 1985]] [[Category:American companies established in 1985]] [[Category:Companies based in St. Joseph County, Indiana]]

revision.text:
'''Rom Houben''' is a Belgian man presumed comatose and in a [[vegetative state]] for 23 years after a near-fatal [[automobile]] accident, but according to several of his caregivers, was conscious and paralyzed during the entirety of his hospital stay.<ref>Allan Hall (23 November 2009). "[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1230092/Rom-Houben-Patient-trapped-23-year-coma-conscious-along.html 'I screamed, but there was nothing to hear': Man trapped in 23-year 'coma' reveals horror of being unable to tell doctors he was conscious]". ''Mail Online''.</ref><ref name="bbc1">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8375326.stm|title=Paralysed Belgian misdiagnosed as in coma for 23 years|date=24 November 2009|work=BBC News|accessdate=24 November 2009}}</ref><ref>Raf Casert (23 November 2009). "[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/11/23/rom-houben-man-in-coma-fo_n_367798.html Rom Houben, man in coma for 23 years, was fully conscious, mom says]". ''The Huffington Post''.</ref> In 2010, the claim was rejected when communication could not be repeated with a different facilitator and by hiding the object to be identified from the view of the [[Facilitated communication|facilitator]].<ref name=hoax>{{Cite news|author=Scott Hensley |title=Book-writing man in coma fails communication test |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/health/2010/02/bookwriting_man_in_coma_flunks.html |quote=But further tests show the man, Rom Houben, was unable to correctly identify simple words and objects presented to him by researchers, his neurologist Steven Laureys tells NPR's Jon Hamilton. |work=[[National Public Radio]] |date=17 February 2010 |accessdate=2010-02-19 }}</ref>
==Background== Houben was diagnosed with total [[locked-in syndrome]] by Belgian [[neurologist]] [[Steven Laureys]] in 2006 with the help of modern brain imaging techniques and equipment.<ref name="Guardian">Kate Connolly (23 November 2009). "[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/23/man-trapped-coma-23-years Car crash victim trapped in 'coma' for 23 years was conscious]". guardian.co.uk.</ref> He now apparently communicates by typing into a keyboard with his right hand supported by a [[Facilitated communication|communication facilitator]].<ref>Mark Memmott (23 November 2009). "[https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2009/11/for_23_years_man_thought_to_be.html For 23 years man thought to be in coma tried to 'scream', and no one heard]". [[National Public Radio]].</ref><ref name="MSNBC_video">{{cite video | people = | date = | title = Video showing facilitated communication with Rom Houben | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31388323/vp/34111007#34111007 | medium = video | publisher = [[MSNBC]] | accessdate = | time = 0:12 }}</ref> However, the claims that Houben is able to communicate by typing have been widely disputed.<ref name=Caplan1/><ref name=Appel/><ref name=Randi/><ref name=Novella/>
Houben's case is used to question the current methods of diagnosing vegetative state and to arguments against withholding care from such patients.<ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="BMC">{{Cite journal| title = Diagnostic accuracy of the vegetative and minimally conscious state: Clinical consensus versus standardized neurobehavioral assessment | author = Caroline Schnakers, Audrey Vanhaudenhuyse, Joseph Giacino, Manfredi Ventura, Melanie Boly, Steve Majerus, Gustave Moonen, [[Steven Laureys]] | journal = [[BMC Neurology]] | year = 2009 | volume = 9 | pages = 35 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2377-9-35 | url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2377/9/35/ | pmid=19622138 | pmc=2718857}}</ref> However, some [[bioethicists]] believe that the case, if confirmed, may provide ''stronger'' arguments for withdrawing or withholding from vegetative patients.<ref name=Appel/>
While Houben was diagnosed in 2006, his case, first reported in a ''[[BMC Neurology]]'' paper in July 2009 without him being named,<ref name="BMC"/> was only brought to wider public attention after German weekly magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' ran a story on it in November 2009 which was subsequently picked up by media outlets around the world, receiving extensive coverage.<ref name="wired">{{Cite news|author=[[Brandon Keim]] |coauthors= |title=Reborn coma man's words may be bogus |url=https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2009/11/houben-communication/ |quote= |work=[[Wired Science]] |date=24 November 2009 |accessdate=2010-02-26 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=han|title=Komapatient war 23 Jahre bei Bewusstsein|language=German|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/medizin/0,1518,662627,00.html |work=[[Spiegel Online]]|date=21 November 2009}}</ref><ref>Manfred Dworschak (23 November 2009). "[http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/0,1518,662625,00.html „Meine zweite Geburt"]". ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' 48/2009, pp. 134-137.</ref>
==Controversy== Bioethicist [[Jacob M. Appel]] of [[New York University]] has suggested that the case may be either "a matter of wishful thinking", or "a cruel and [[Psychological manipulation|manipulative]] hoax" that will be used by political conservatives in their public relations campaign against the [[right to die]].<ref name=Appel>[[Jacob M. Appel]] (24 November 2009). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jacob-m-appel/the-rom-houben-tragedy-an_b_370032.html The Rom Houben Tragedy and the Case for Active Euthanasia]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved on 29 November 2009.</ref>
The method used to allegedly communicate with Houben is known as "[[facilitated communication]]",<ref name="MSNBC_video"/> which the [[Association for Behavior Analysis International]], the [[American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry]] and the [[American Association on Mental Retardation]] have called a "discredited technique", the use of which is "unwarranted and unethical".<ref name=Caplan1>[[Arthur Caplan]] (24 November 2009). [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/34132340 Coherent after coma? Not so sure]. msnbc.com. Retrieved on 29 November 2009.</ref> Skeptics, including [[PZ Myers]] and [[James Randi]], contend that facilitated communication does not involve actual communication with the disabled, but rather with the people playing the role of the "facilitator".<ref>PZ Myers (24 November 2009). "[http://scienceblogs.com/pharyngula/2009/11/really_this_guy_is_conscious.php Really? This guy is conscious?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127052139/http://scienceblogs.com/pharyngula/2009/11/really_this_guy_is_conscious.php |date=27 November 2009 }}</ref> Randi writes that claims of Houben's facilitated communication amount to a "cruel farce."<ref name=Randi>James Randi (25 November 2009). "[http://www.randi.org/site/index.php/swift-blog/783-this-cruel-farce-has-to-stop.html This cruel farce has to stop!]". James Randi Educational Foundation.</ref> Video footage shows the "facilitator", Linda Wouters, holding Houben's hand as his finger is being used to type at a rapid pace, even though the subject appears to be slumped over with his eyes closed.<ref name='blind_typing'>"[http://news.ninemsn.com.au/world/975121/belgian-coma-man-was-just-awake-for-23-years Belgian coma man was awake for 23 years]". ''ninemsn''. 24 November 2009.</ref> [[Neurologist]] [[Steven Novella]] argued that there was "little doubt" that Houben's typing is the result of bogus facilitated communication.<ref name=Novella>[[Steven Novella]] (25 November 2009). [http://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/?p=2838 Man in Coma 23 Years – Is He Really Conscious?]. Retrieved on 29 November 2009.</ref>
Additionally, [[Arthur Caplan]], a bioethics professor at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], has claimed that the statements Houben allegedly made through his facilitator seem unnatural for someone disabled and unable to speak for decades.<ref name="wired"/><ref name="msnbc1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/34109227/ns/health-more_health_news/?GT1=43001|title=Man says emergence from ‘coma’ like rebirth|last=Associated Press|date=24 November 2009|accessdate=24 November 2009}}</ref> Through Wouters, Houben is quoted as saying "Now I can communicate and talk via facilitated communication. Not everyone believes in this form of communication. It is a controversial method but, for me, it is vital to life. At last, my views can be heard and my feelings expressed."<ref name='tol'>David Charter (25 November 2009). "[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/health/article6930608.ece Mystery as coma survivor Rom Houben finds voice at his fingertips]". ''Times Online''.</ref>
Initially, Laureys said that he had verified that the facilitated communication was genuine, by showing Houben objects when the facilitator was not present in the room, and later asking Houben to recall those objects.<ref name='tol'/> Novella suggested that Laureys had not used proper controls.<ref name=Novella/>
In an interview with the Belgian newspaper ''[[De Standaard]]'', Laureys stated that he was not involved in the choice of communication method and refused to comment on its validity. He even claimed to be "a skeptic [himself]" and acknowledged that "the bad reputation of some forms [of facilitated communication] is justified". He also claimed that Houben's case was only made public because ''Der Spiegel'' wanted to report on his study and was looking for a "human element" to the story: "I knew that Rom and his family were willing to collaborate because they had done so before [for a Flemish TV channel]." However, he also criticized some of the negative feedback for "judging the evidence only on the basis of some video footage" and declared that "given time, we will look scientifically into the different ways of communication. For us, this seems to be the proper way."<ref>Filip Salmon (28 November 2009). "[http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=H12IVKE5 Rom is geen circusnummer (Rom is no circus act)]". ''De Standaard''. (in Dutch)</ref>
==Disproof== Laureys later concluded that messages attributed to Houben through Wouters' facilitation were not, in fact, coming from Houben after all. After the early tests, further testing met with resistance. Using a different facilitator, subsequent testing under properly controlled conditions in which fifteen objects which were shown to Houben over a period of weeks was performed, Houben was unable to communicate knowledge of any of the objects which had been shown to him during the facilitator's absence.<ref name=hoax/><ref>Manfred Dworschak (13 February 2010). "[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,677537,00.html Communicating with those trapped within their brains]". ''Der Spiegel''.</ref> Novella attributed Laureys' prior error to likely insufficient experience with facilitated communication.<ref name=hoax />
==See also== *[[Clever Hans]] *[[Ideomotor effect]] *[[Locked-in syndrome]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{Medical ethics cases}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Seeds of Hope: HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia | image = | caption = | director = [[Dorothy Fadiman]] | producer = Henock Hailu, Amy Hill, Matt Luotto, Shenaz Zack | narrator = [[Dorothy Fadiman]] | music = Aster Aweke | released = {{Film date|2004|02}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = Amharic and English }} '''''Seeds of Hope: HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia''''' is a set of five [[documentary]] films about individuals and organizations working to break the silence, lift the stigma and prevent the spread of [[HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia]]. The films focus on activists, family members, humanitarian groups, and health care professionals, all acting as advocates for awareness. The films were directed by filmmaker, [[Dorothy Fadiman]]. The films are in [[Amharic]] with English subtitles.
The five films in the series are: "From Risk to Action: Women & HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia (2006)," "Breaking the Silence: Lifting the Stigma of HIV/AIDS (2006)," "Stepping Forward: Men Teaching and Learning about HIV/AIDS (2006)," "HIV/AIDS Awareness: Approaches to Prevention (2006)," and "Whose Children Are They Now?: AIDS Orphans in Ethiopia (2006)."
==From Risk to Action: Women & HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia (2006)== This film examines the gender bias and the biology of transmission in Ethiopia which makes women more vulnerable than men to become infected. This film profiles the connection between gender and HIV/AIDS, as well as the work of leaders in education and policy change to improve the status of women.
==Breaking the Silence: Lifting the Stigma of HIV/AIDS (2006)== This film documents [[HIV-positive people]], who speak out despite the risk of social stigma and become active in their communities, working to reduce discrimination and secure better services. This film details their stories and profiles groups that provide counseling, income support, and prevention education.
==Stepping Forward: Men Teaching and Learning about HIV/AIDS (2006)== This film examines certain populations of men, such as truck drivers and soldiers, who suffer high rates of infection. The film details the intensive education programs in Ethiopia to reach such individuals to heighten their awareness of safer sex practices.
==HIV/AIDS Awareness: Approaches to Prevention (2006)== This film follows Ethiopians who are working to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS through education, communication through radio, television, and print media. The film also chronicles preventive education through street theater, coffee ceremonies, and funeral gatherings. The film features a home video of the wedding of [[Alebachew Teka]], who included many HIV-positive children as honored guests.
==Whose Children Are They Now?: AIDS Orphans in Ethiopia (2006)== The AIDS epidemic has left more than one million children without parents in Ethiopia. This film explores the stories of compassionate caregivers and the young people for whom they care.
==Screenings==
*2006 [https://archive.is/20121214184725/http://www.jhsph.edu/gatesinstitute/policy_practice/conferences-meetings/fp-hivmtg/agenda.html Linking Reproductive Health, Family Planning and HIV/AIDS in Africa ] in [[Addis Ababa]], Ethiopia
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links ==
* {{Official website|http://concentric.org/films/seeds_of_hope.html }} * [http://vimeo.com/25115720 From Risk to Action: Women and HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia] on vimeo.com * [https://archive.org/details/From_Risk_to_Action_Amharic_DBFadiman_2006 From Risk to Action: Women and HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia] on archive.com * {{YouTube|Td4KHp5zzGk|From Risk to Action: Women and HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia}} * [http://vimeo.com/31827356 Breaking the Silence: Lifting the Stigma of AIDS in Ethiopia] on vimeo.com * [https://archive.org/details/Breaking_the_Silence_Amharic_DBFadiman_2006 Breaking the Silence: Lifting the Stigma of AIDS in Ethiopia] on archive.com * {{YouTube|GHr3XhVs29w|Breaking the Silence: Lifting the Stigma of AIDS in Ethiopia}} * [http://vimeo.com/31245210 Stepping Forward: Men Teaching and Learning about HIV/AIDS ] on vimeo.com * [https://archive.org/details/Stepping_Forward_Amharic_DBFadiman_2006 Stepping Forward: Men Teaching and Learning about HIV/AIDS] on archive.org * [http://vimeo.com/31264517 HIV/AIDS Awareness: Approaches to Prevention ] on vimeo.com * [https://archive.org/details/hiv_awareness_in_ethiopia_2006 HIV/AIDS AWARENESS in ETHIOPIA: Approaches to Prevention] on archive.org * [http://vimeo.com/31811184 Whose Children Are They Now? AIDS Orphans in Ethiopia] on vimeo.com * [https://archive.org/details/whose_children_are_they_now_2006 Whose Children Are They Now? AIDS Orphans in Ethiopia ] on archive.org * [http://vimeo.com/32881790 World's AIDS Day Show Dec 2011] at [http://www.communitymediacenter.net Midpeninsula Community Media Center] * [https://archive.is/20130122151815/http://www.ethiopianreview.com/archive/390651562108211102_ethiopia.html Interview with Producer of Documentary Movie on HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia EthiopianReview.com] *[http://aidsvideos.org/amharic.shtml Seed Films from] AIDSvideos.org * [http://www.wmm.com/filmcatalog/makers/fm29.shtml Women Make Movies] * [http://www.tadias.com/v1n5/index.html "Seeds" Film Mentioned in the October-November 2003 Issue of Tadias Online] * [http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/11.06.03/fadiman-0345.html Screening of "Seeds of Hope: HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia" , Nov 6, 2003] by [[Richard von Busack]], [[Metro Silicon Valley]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{more citations needed|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox biodatabase|description=Drug target database|logo=[[File:Ttd logo.png|TTD log|120px]]|laboratory=[http://bidd.nus.edu.sg/group2017/ Bioinformatics and Drug Design Group (BIDD)] [https://www.idrblab.org/ Innovative Drug Research and Bioinformatics Group (IDRB)]|released=15 Sep, 2017|version=6.1.01|license=Free access|url=https://db.idrblab.org/ttd/|title=Therapeutic Target Database (TTD)|pmid=29140520}} '''Therapeutic Target Database'''<ref name="pmid19933260">{{cite journal|last=|first=|date=|year=2018|title=Therapeutic target database update 2018: enriched resource for facilitating bench-to-clinic research of targeted therapeutics.|url=https://academic.oup.com/nar/article/doi/10.1093/nar/gkx1076/4621327|journal=Nucleic Acids Res.|volume=46|issue=D1|pages=D1121–D1127|doi=10.1093/nar/gkx1076|pmc=5753365|pmid=29140520|via=|vauthors=Li YH, Yu CY, Li XX, Zhang P, Tang J, Yang Q, Fu T, Zhang X, Cui X, Tu G, Zhang Y, Li S, Yang F, Sun Q, Qin C, Zeng X, Chen Z, Chen YZ, Zhu F}}</ref> ('''TTD''') is a [[database]] provided by [http://bidd.nus.edu.sg/group2017/ Bioinformatics and Drug Design Group] in [[National University of Singapore]] and [https://www.idrblab.org/ Innovative Drug Research and Bioinformatics Group] (IDRB) in [http://www.zju.edu.cn/ Zhejiang University], which provides information about the known and explored therapeutic [[protein]] and [[nucleic acid]] targets,<ref name="pmid12209152">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hopkins AL, Groom CR | title = The druggable genome. | journal = Nature Reviews Drug Discovery | volume = 1 | issue = 9 | pages = 727–30 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12209152 | doi = 10.1038/nrd892 }}</ref><ref name="pmid17139284">{{cite journal |vauthors=Overington JP, Al-Lazikani B, Hopkins AL | title = How many drug targets are there? | journal = Nature Reviews Drug Discovery | volume = 5 | issue = 12 | pages = 993–6 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17139284 | doi = 10.1038/nrd2199 }}</ref><ref name="pmid16714488">{{cite journal |vauthors=Zheng CJ, Han LY, Yap CW, Ji ZL, Cao ZW, Chen YZ | title = Therapeutic targets: progress of their exploration and investigation of their characteristics. | journal = Pharmacol. Rev. | volume = 58 | issue = 2 | pages = 259–79 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16714488 | doi = 10.1124/pr.58.2.4 }}</ref> the targeted disease, pathway information and the corresponding drugs directed at each of these targets. Also included in this database are links to relevant databases containing information about target function, sequence, 3D structure, ligand binding properties, [[enzyme]] nomenclature and drug structure, therapeutic class, clinical development status.<ref name="pmid19933260" />
==Content== This database currently contains 2,025 targets, including 364 successful, 286 clinical trial, 44 discontinued and 1,331 research targets, 17,816 drugs, including 1,540 approved, 1,423 clinical trial, 14,853 experimental drugs and 3,681 multi-target agents (14,170 small molecules and 652 antisense drugs with available structure or oligonucleotide sequence). Targets and drugs in this database cover 61 protein biochemical class and 140 drug therapeutic classes respectively.<ref name="pmid11752352">{{cite journal |vauthors=Chen X, Ji ZL, Chen YZ | title = TTD: Therapeutic Target Database. | journal = Nucleic Acids Res. | volume = 30 | issue = 1 | pages = 412–5 | year = 2002 | pmid = 11752352 | doi = 10.1093/nar/30.1.412 | pmc = 99057 }}</ref>
==Target validation data== In the 2011 version of TTD, target validation information has been integrated. Target validation normally requires the determination that the target is expressed in the disease-relevant cells/tissues, it can be directly modulated by a drug or drug-like molecule with adequate potency in biochemical assay, and that target modulation in cell and/or animal models ameliorates the relevant disease phenotype.<ref name="pmid14526386">{{cite journal | author = Lindsay MA. | title = Target discovery. | journal = Nature Reviews Drug Discovery | volume = 2 | issue = 10 | pages = 831–8 | year = 2003 | pmid = 14526386 | doi = 10.1038/nrd1202}}</ref><ref name="pmid19646923">{{cite journal |vauthors=Vidalin O, Muslmani M, Estienne C, Echchakir H, Abina AM | title = In vivo target validation using gene invalidation, RNA interference and protein functional knockout models: it is the time to combine. | journal = Current Opinion in Pharmacology | volume = 9 | issue = 5 | pages = 669–76 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19646923 | doi = 10.1016/j.coph.2009.06.017}}</ref> Therefore, TTD collects three types of target validation data: experimentally determined potency of drugs against their primary target or targets, observed potency or effects of drugs against disease models (cell-lines, ex-vivo, in-vivo models) linked to their primary target or targets, and the observed effects of target knockout, knockdown, RNA interference, transgenetic, antibody or antisense treated in-vivo models. Currently, TTD provides complete or partial validation information for 932 targets (351 successful, 252 clinical trial, 34 discontinued and 295 research targets). All validation information can be retrieved from Target Validation Page.
==Quantitative structure-activity relationship models against specific target== Knowledge of developed QSAR models for different molecular scaffolds active against different targets is highly useful for facilitating further drug development and lead optimisation efforts.<ref name="pmid20337590">{{cite journal |vauthors=Sprous DG, Palmer RK, Swanson JT, Lawless M | title = QSAR in the pharmaceutical research setting: QSAR models for broad, large problems. | journal = Curr Top Med Chem | volume = 10 | issue = 6 | pages = 619–37 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20337590 | doi=10.2174/156802610791111506}}</ref><ref name="pmid19569715">{{cite journal |vauthors=Mittal RR, McKinnon RA, Sorich MJ | title = Comparison data sets for benchmarking QSAR methodologies in lead optimization. | journal = J. Chem. Inf. Model. | volume = 49 | issue = 7 | pages = 1810–20 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19569715 | doi = 10.1021/ci900117m}}</ref><ref name="pmid16533155">{{cite journal |vauthors=Dudek AZ, Arodz T, Gálvez J | title = Computational methods in developing quantitative structure-activity relationships (QSAR): a review. | journal = Comb Chem High Throughput Screen | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = 213–28 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16533155 | doi=10.2174/138620706776055539}}</ref> Current TTD has 841 ligand-based QSAR models for active compounds of 228 chemical types against 121 targets. These QSAR models can be accessed in Target-based QSAR Models Page.
==Multi-target agents== Multi-target agents directed at selected multiple targets have been increasingly explored for enhanced therapeutic efficacies, improved safety profiles, and reduced resistance activities by simultaneously modulating the activity of a primary target and the counteractive elements.<ref name="pmid15688074">{{cite journal |vauthors=Keith CT, Borisy AA, Stockwell BR | title = Multicomponent therapeutics for networked systems. | journal = Nature Reviews Drug Discovery | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | pages = 71–8 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15688074 | doi=10.1038/nrd1609}}</ref><ref name="pmid16731745">{{cite journal |vauthors=Smalley KS, Haass NK, Brafford PA, Lioni M, Flaherty KT, Herlyn M | title = Multiple signaling pathways must be targeted to overcome drug resistance in cell lines derived from melanoma metastases. | journal = Mol. Cancer Ther. | volume = 5 | issue = 5 | pages = 1136–44 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16731745 | doi=10.1158/1535-7163.MCT-06-0084}}</ref><ref name="pmid7542804">{{cite journal |vauthors=Larder BA, Kemp SD, Harrigan PR | title = Potential mechanism for sustained antiretroviral efficacy of AZT-3TC combination therapy. | journal = Science | volume = 269 | issue = 5224 | pages = 696–9 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7542804 | doi=10.1126/science.7542804}}</ref> Multi-target agent against a target-pair refers to a compound active against both targets at potency values of ≤ 20 [[micromolar|μM]] regardless of their possible activities against other targets. These multi-target agents can be retrieved from Multi-Target Agents Page.
==Related Databases== * [http://www.drugbank.ca/ DrugBank]<ref name="pmid18048412">{{cite journal |vauthors=Wishart DS, Knox C, Guo AC, Cheng D, Shrivastava S, Tzur D, Gautam B, Hassanali M | title = DrugBank: a knowledgebase for drugs, drug actions and drug targets. | journal = Nucleic Acids Res. | volume = 36 | issue = 1 | pages = 901–6 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18048412 | doi = 10.1093/nar/gkm958 | pmc = 2238889 }}</ref> * [http://www.bindingdb.org/bind/index.jsp Binding DB]<ref name="pmid17145705">{{cite journal |vauthors=Liu T, Lin Y, Wen X, Jorissen RN, Gilson MK | title = BindingDB: a web-accessible database of experimentally determined protein-ligand binding affinities. | journal = Nucleic Acids Res. | volume = 35 | issue = 1 | pages = 198–201 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17145705 | doi = 10.1093/nar/gkl999 | pmc = 1751547 }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://db.idrblab.org/ttd/ Therapeutic Target Database Home page] * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29140520 Article on PubMed]
[[Category:Proteins]] [[Category:Pharmacology literature]] [[Category:Chemical databases]] [[Category:Medical databases]] [[Category:Drugs in Singapore]]
[[de:Target (Biologie)]] [[sl:Biološka tarča]]
